txt: Several times in each of the last few decades, Silicon Valley has been home to a truly big gamble. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh transformed the computer industry, but other high-stakes wagers like the Amiga or the Go Corporation have fizzled. In fact, most of the valley is big gambles have failed for setting goals that proved far too ambitious. In the early 1980 is there was Trilogy, a premature effort to build an ultrafast mainframe computer. In the early 1990 is, Microunity caught the valley is imagination with a microprocessor intended to be the standard for interactive cable systems, which failed to emerge.

Ending more than two years of very public indecision, Apple is co-founder, Steve Jobs, said today he was dropping the ''interim'' from ''interim chief executive,'' the title under which he has led the company back into prosperity in the last two and a half years. The announcement that he was staying on indefinitely at the computer company he co-founded almost 25 years ago was made in typical Jobsian style before an overflow crowd of more than 4,000 Macintosh users -- as a footnote to a lengthy keynote presentation at the company is biannual Macworld exhibition, which opened here today.

Paul Krugman column says Bill Gates, who is stepping down as Microsoft is chief executive officer, was able to push aside IBM and Apple and dominate the new electronic economy because he realized importance of 'network externalities,' the incentive most people have to use the same software--or video format, or typewriter keyboard--that everyone else uses

Apple surpasses analysts' estimates for its first quarter ended Jan 1, 2000, and grateful board thanks its chief executive Steve Jobs for company is turnaround by giving him Gulfstream jet and 10 million stock options; Apple director Jerry York says under Jobs and his executive team, Apple is market valuation increased from less than $2 billion to more than $16 billion, and that $90 million cost to Apple for jet and tax offset is about 6.5 percent of gain; Apple reports earnings of $183 million, up 20 percent from $152 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 37 percent, to $2.34 billion, from $1.71 billion in first quarter of fiscal 1999

State of the Art column by Peter Lewis describes Apple is new Internet-based services, called iTools; iTools and companion services, iCards and iReview, include free e-mail accounts, electronic greeting card service, human-based system for reviewing other Web sites and personal data backup and storage service; services like these already exist everywhere on Internet; key is that Apple, because it controls software at both ends of Internet connection, can do things other software and Internet companies cannot do, like forge seamless links and bridges between Macs that may be on adjoining desks or on separate continents; Apple services are free to users with access to relatively current Macintosh with Power PC processor

Analysis of Justice Department is tentative proposal that would force Microsoft Corp to break off its industry-standard Windows operating system into one company, and its Office applications software business and most other operations into a second company; says broad idea behind department is plan is to create incentives for increased competition among operating systems and in related businesses; holds one reason Windows has no significant competitors is that Microsoft generally does not create software for non-Windows operating systems, with exception of Apple is; holds Microsoft argues that new application-software company will have no more incentive to write for smaller operating systems than is now the case

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert. * FIONA APPLE, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, Manhattan, (212) 496-7070. Fiona Apple is last New York appearance, at Roseland, ended ignominiously when the singer and songwriter, unable to hear herself in the monitors, threw a fit of agony so long and difficult to watch it made ''Saving Private Ryan'' seem like a laugh fest. Maybe her behavior was not professional, but she did it for the sake of her music, which is too complicated to be sacrificed to a poor sound system. Now she will attempt her gorgeously, gracefully tangled songs in a different setting. Here is hoping that the sound system cooperates and, if not, that she rides the wave. Tonight at 8; admission is $27.50 (Ann Powers).

NEW YORK MANHATTAN: BUS WORKERS PROTEST A small group of New York Apple Tours workers gathered at City Hall yesterday to protest the shutdown of their double-decker bus tour company on Wednesday. Meanwhile, hundreds of people with tickets for Apple tours gathered outside the company is Midtown office to demand refunds. Officials at Gray Line, another tour company, said they were accepting New York Apple tickets. The State Department of Motor Vehicles suspended the registrations of all 63 Apple Tours buses after a pedestrian was struck and killed by one of the vehicles last week. Jayson Blair (NYT)

NEW YORK MANHATTAN: BUS PLAN A Manhattan judge proposed yesterday that state lawyers hammer out a temporary compromise with a suspended bus company, New York Apple Tours, and allow drivers without violations to return to the road until a final determination about the company is license is made. The city suspended the company is license after one of its buses struck and killed a man in Manhattan on May 22. At the hearing yesterday, Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob asked both sides to meet on Friday to try to reach a compromise. Katherine Finkelstein (NYT)

BLOOR-James, 92, died May 31st at Hilton Head Island, SC. He was born September 16, 1907 to Walter and Isabelle Bloor. He attended Barnard School for Boys and Rockland Academy. He was employed by Thompson-Starrett Co. and in 1932 he went to work for Chase National Bank, (Chase Manhattan Bank). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy. After the War, he returned to Chase where he stayed until 1955 when he left to become Executive Vice President of Central Savings Bank, (Apple Bank for Savings). He was named President in 1961 and retired as Chairman of the Board in 1972. Following retirement, he was a consultant for the National Bank of North America until 1974 when he was chosen by the Bankruptcy Court to act as Trustee of Investors Funding Corp. In addition, he served on the Board of Directors of Nyack Hospital, Empire National Bank, Sandoz Inc., Alico Financial Corp., Mercantile National Bank, The James Lee Foundation, Savings Bank Trust Co., Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, New York State Employees Retirement System, National Association of Savings Banks and Guardian Life Insurance Company. Mr. Bloor resided in Grandview-on-Hudson in Rockland County, New York. He was a Trustee of the Village, Mayor and Police Justice. In 1992, he moved to Hilton Head Island, SC. Survived by his wife, Florence; 3 children, James Bloor of Santa Ana, CA, Joan Faccioli of Hilton Head and Ann Gray of Eastham, MA; 8 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions to the Kerry Fund c/o Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, 1954 Cotner Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90025. Services were held on Hilton Head Island.

NEW YORK MANHATTAN: APPLE TOURS CRITICIZED The city is Consumer Affairs Department has accused New York Apple Tours of lying to customers since the bus company was ordered off the road. The department said Friday that Apple Tours employees have told tourists that Apple Tours was the same company as New York Double Decker Buses. Double Decker is a separate company. It agreed to honor Apple Tours tickets sold before the May 31 suspension of Apple Tours' license. The president of Apple Tours, Hayim Grant, above, denied the charge. (AP)

(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A PLACE IN THE COUNTRY, by Laura Shaine Cunningham. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Years of fruitless wishing for the great good place finally paid off for the author with a gracious old house upstate; her wisdom is shown by acknowledging that snakes and bad neighbors go with the territory just as flowers and moonbeams do. SYDNEY: The Story of a City, by Geoffrey Moorhouse. (Harcourt, $25.) A virtuoso exposition of Sydney and the social history that has formed it, from the first Europeans and the British convicts through the gold rushes to the variety of today is Asian immigrants. A RUM AFFAIR: A True Story of Botanical Fraud, by Karl Sabbagh. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A grave and witty account of a British amateur botanist who in the late 1940 is caught a professor faking evidence to suit his theory about the last ice age and the Hebridean island of Rum, then sealed his report of the fraud in his college library (it leaked anyhow). SISTER: The Life of the Legendary American Interior Decorator Mrs. Henry Parish II, by Apple Parish Bartlett and Susan Bartlett Crater. (St. Martin is, $35.) An oral history, compiled by the daughter and granddaughter of the formidably descended aristocrat who went into the decorating business in 1933 and lived a life characterized by robust frivolity and lots of hard work. THE QUESTION OF BRUNO, by Aleksandar Hemon. (Nan Talese/Doubleday, $22.95.) Mostly fictional (but who can say for sure?) stories and a novella, invoking both the terrible facts of Bosnia and Yugoslavia and the years of the author is childhood, when there was yet hope for both. THE GENTLEMAN FROM NEW YORK. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: A Biography, by Godfrey Hodgson. (Houghton Mifflin, $38.) A life of the right is favorite liberal, or the left is favorite neocon, always intelligent, usually correct and at peace with his impending retirement; by a British journalist and longtime friend. DREAM STUFF: Stories, by David Malouf. (Pantheon, $22.) Australia, in the short fiction of this collection, is a place of surprises and changing potential where history itself is sometimes in question and characters protest against loss, though the author seems to assure us that nothing is lost forever. THE LOST LEGENDS OF NEW JERSEY, by Frederick Reiken. (Harcourt, $24.) The drama of sheer ordinariness receives its celebration in this novel set in northern New Jersey about 1980; the Jewish and Italian families who inhabit it struggle (especially the teenagers) for both stability and poetry. TOUCHING PEACE: From the Oslo Accord to a Final Agreement, by Yossi Beilin. (Weidenfeld/Trafalgar Square, $50.) Israel is chief negotiator at Oslo and Stockholm gives a personal account of the secret talks with the P.L.O. that outlined the probable shape of any future Middle East peace, regardless of the outcome of the recent Barak-Arafat-Clinton meetings at Camp David.
State of the Art column appraises Apple is new Power Mac G4 Cube computer

(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) LEFT BACK: A Century of Failed School Reforms, by Diane Ravitch. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) An education expert who has often run with conservatives argues that 20th-century ''progressive'' theorists watered down education for non-elites in the name of ''life adjustment'' and other slogans, depriving those very groups of the knowledge to help them rise. THE GENTLEMAN FROM NEW YORK. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: A Biography, by Godfrey Hodgson. (Houghton Mifflin, $38.) A life of the right is favorite liberal, or the left is favorite neocon, always intelligent, usually correct and at peace with his impending retirement; by a British journalist and friend. KHOMEINI: Life of the Ayatollah, by Baqer Moin. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin is, $27.95.) An Iranian (and former Muslim seminarian) gives a deft account of the background and rise to power of the gifted, shrewd cleric and politician who destroyed Iran is monarchy and forever changed the course of its history. AN OBEDIENT FATHER, by Akhil Sharma. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The main narrator in this novel by a New York investment banker is a low, corrupt functionary in the Delhi school system. It is easy to brand him despicable because he is, but his power to do ill is limited, his personality complex and his author compassionate. BLOOD OF THE LIBERALS, by George Packer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Liberalism, under one or another definition, is the force that shaped and eventually failed the author is grandfather (a Congressman from Alabama), his father (a legal scholar and student of procedure) and himself (once a Peace Corps volunteer, now a writer, and though bloodied not yet totally bowed). A HOLE IN THE EARTH, by Robert Bausch. (Harcourt, $24.) Bausch is fourth novel concerns Henry Porter, 39, the sole flop in a family of successes, whose fixation in preternatural adolescence is mitigated by his own humiliations and the kindness of others. THE SECRET PARTS OF FORTUNE: Three Decades of Intense Investigations and Edgy Enthusiasms, by Ron Rosenbaum. (Random House, $29.95.) A generous collection of journalism by a writer who has exposed himself to many of the great obsessions of the 20th century without losing his curiosity, his skepticism or his willingness to listen. I LOVED YOU ALL, by Paula Sharp. (Hyperion, $23.95.) An old-fashioned storytelling novel about the escalating defiance of hard-line anti-abortionists in the 1970 is; the leading character (on the side that is clearly not the author is) has the depth and energy to become indispensable to people whose lives or children are out of control. SISTER: The Life of the Legendary American Interior Decorator Mrs. Henry Parish II, by Apple Parish Bartlett and Susan Bartlett Crater. (St. Martin is, $35.) An oral history, compiled by the daughter and granddaughter of the formidably descended aristocrat who went into the decorating business in 1933 and lived a life characterized by robust frivolity and hard work.

John Sculley, former chief executive of Apple, and his brothers Arthur and David run small venture capital firm that finances Internet start-ups; Sculley focuses on start-ups like TechSmart, company founded by entrepreneur Dennis Lynch, and serves as mentor and friend as well as investor; so far, Sculley Brothers has invested in 26 start-ups; four are either profitable or breaking even; three of five companies they backed that have gone public now trade at rock-bottom prices

(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) LAST NIGHT A DJ SAVED MY LIFE: The History of the Disc Jockey, by Bill Brewster and Frank Broughton. (Grove, paper, $14.) A lively account of the unsung heroes of popular music, the club D.J. is who in their enthusiasm and their technical competence developed the ears of nearly everyone else and led the music almost everywhere it has gone. JEW VS. JEW: The Struggle for the Soul of American Jewry, by Samuel Freedman. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A journalism professor, once a reporter for The Times, explores the frictions that have risen in America, especially between the Orthodox and the less Orthodox, and envisions a possible future in which religion alone will be the determinant of who is Jewish and who not. THE RULES OF ENGAGEMENT, by Catherine Bush. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A novel with the nerve to use war as a metaphor for the travails of love; its protagonist, a graduate in war studies, has fled Canada after two men fought a duel over her. The last time Apple introduced a fundamentally new operating system was in 1984, when System 1.0 shipped with the original Macintosh computer. Ronald Reagan was president, Steve Jobs was the chairman of Apple, and the consumer embrace of Windows was still several years away. (In those days many computers ran on the DOS platform, which involved a lot of typed commands instead of pointing and clicking.)

Apple introduces beta version of its new Mac OSX (10) operating system software, which is based on Unix operating system and has a new interface, called Aqua; people who pay $29.95 for chance to find bugs and glitches in this test version will be surveyed by company for comment

Steve Jobs, Apple. is chief executive, unveiled a major upgrade of the company is operating-system software here Wednesday that he hailed as "the future of the Macintosh.".The system, called the Mac OSX, features a new look, simpl

After years of false starts, Apple introduced its first radically changed operating system since the original Macintosh entered the market in 1984. The much-anticipated new system, called Mac OSX, was released to the public in an evaluation version for $29.95.

Apple released a work-in-progress version of its new operating system -- Mac OSX -- which had Macintosh addicts and computer-industry analysts buzzing. The beta software, publicly available from Apple is Web site for $29.95, is the first look at a complete overhaul of the system that was first released in 1984 with the original Macintosh. Mac OSX combines an intuitive user interface on top of a robust infrastructure based on the Unix operating system. The final version is scheduled for release in 2001, when it may help restore Apple is shine as an industry innovator in a marketplace dominated by Microsoft Windows. J. D. Biersdorfer

Computer makers, including Apple, Sony and Dell, are trying to spice up the market by providing digital video editing capabilities that can turn a passive computer user into a movie director; in addition, there is the new Lego Studios Steve Spielberg MovieMaker Set; lure of being able to tell personal stories by just cutting and pasting on a computer proves irresistible for some cosumers, but industry experts wonder how many people will actually make movies

Henry Fountain article on spending a weekend making a short video of a youth soccer match, using Apple Mac DV video editing software; says making a movie is a fine idea in theory, but one that would take time from things he would rather do

William Hill was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple Mac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a résumé, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new Mac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable Mac without video editing.

IT'S easy to forget what a skillful work Robert Zemeckis is FORREST GUMP (1994) is. Six years later, the special effects (from the hero, chatting with presidents to Gary Sinise is amputated legs) do not seem so amazing, but Tom Hanks is gut-level sincerity in the title role does. This is the story of a simple man is life, his love for one woman (Robin Wright, who is lovely as the emotionally bruised Jenny) and his encounters with Elivs, J.F.K., Bear Bryant, Dick Cavett, the Black Panthers, Vietnam, shrimp boats, Apple stock and long-distance running. ''Forrest Gump'' won six Oscars, including best picture, best actor and best director, and it proved that an I. of 75 and a good heart can get big cosmic free-for-all. PASSIONATE MINDS: Women Rewriting the World, by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Vintage, $13.) These brief profiles of women writers like Gertrude Stein, Ayn Rand, Eudora Welty and Doris Lessing, all originally published in The New Yorker, are unified by their subjects' intense need to transcend the limitations of their own lives through language and storytelling. The book is an ''adroit melding of biography and criticism'' that ' isparkles with intelligence, wit and human interest,'' Morris Dickstein wrote in the Book Review last year. EVERYTHING YOU KNOW, by Zo Heller. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $12.95.) Willy Muller is a reptilian celebrity biographer, misanthrope and all-round scuzzy character haunted by the ghost of his estranged daughter, who before her suicide mailed him every journal she would written since she was 9. Writing here last year, Jeff Giles called this ''an acerbic, sneakily touching novel'' that at its best ''calls to mind Martin Amis is phosphorescently nasty oeuvre.'' DARWIN'S WORMS, by Adam Phillips. (Basic Books, $13.) A noted British child psychotherapist reflects on Darwin is lifelong interest in earthworms and Freud is fascination with death, both of which offer cause for celebration in a world abandoned by God. ''Almost invariably lively and entertaining,'' Phillips is essays ''are directed as well toward instructing their audience,'' Steve Marcus said in these pages in 2000. WINSTON AND CLEMENTINE: The Personal Letters of the Churchills. Edited by Mary Soames. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $16.) Winston Churchill and his wife, Clementine, were devoted pen pals throughout 57 years of marriage, as this huge volume edited by their daughter attests. His ' amanly, buoyant style is displayed to great effect,'' Thomas Mallon wrote here in 1999, while ''Clementine . . . can bring Nancy Mitford to mind.'' Churchill Wanted Dead or Alive, by Celia Sandys (Carroll & Graf, $14), is a colorful account of the young Churchill is experiences as a newspaper correspondent in the Boer War, including his escape from a prisoner of war camp. The ''fascinating narrative,'' as put together by his granddaughter, ' amay be the romantic stuff of Victorian adventure fiction, but it has the virtue of being true,'' David Murray wrote here in 2000. AFRICAN FOLKTALES: Traditional Stories of the Black World. Selected and retold by Roger Abrahams. (Pantheon, $18.) An accomplished Africanist plumbs the oral tradition of tribal families throughout the sub-Sahara in this revised anthology of earthy and comedic tales of magic, sultans, ghosts, lovers and animals that behave like people. ''The result is a rousing good read,'' Jason Berry said in the Book Review in 1983. A CONSPIRACY OF PAPER, by David Liss. (Ballantine, $14.) This engaging first novel revolves around a mixed bag of 18th-century characters at the time of the South Sea Bubble, the first stock market crash in the English-speaking world. ''What makes 'A Conspiracy of Paper' so readable is that Liss manages to create a number of arresting side plots featuring everything from the London underworld to boxing to social mores to English anti-Semitism,'' James Polk wrote in these pages last year. THE BLIND SIDE OF THE HEART, by Michael White. (Cliff Street/HarperCollins, $13.) The narrator of this unconventional whodunit is Maggie Quinn, a blunt-spoken housekeeper who wrestles with drink and doubt when her employer, a Roman Catholic priest who once rescued her sanity, is indicted for the murder of an altar boy they both loved. In 1999 our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, admired ' nothe cruel beauty'' of White is ' ispare, unflinching prose.'' MORMON AMERICA: The Power and the Promise, by Richard Ostling and Joan Ostling. (HarperSanFrancisco, $17.) The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, founded by an itinerant treasure hunter from upstate New York in 1830, has a global membership of more than 10 million. This primer, which sorts through the doctrines and practices of the Mormon faith, ''is eminently fair, well researched and exhaustive,'' Timothy Egan wrote here last year. THE MAGIC KINGDOM, by Stanley Elkin. (Dalkey Archive, $12.95.) In this crazy quilt of a novel, a man mourning the loss of his 12-year-old son leads a group of terminally ill children on a trip from England to Disney World. ''Part sick joke, part lyrical meditation on the nature of disease,'' the comic tale ''is both hysterical and profound,'' Max Apple said here in 1985. Scott Veale

MALONEY-James After a short, but courageous battle against cancer, 72 year old James Maloney of Juno Beach, FL, passed away on July 30, 2001. Born to Irish immigrant parents on February 28, 1929 in Cincinnati, OH, Mr. Maloney carved out a full and meaningful life along with an illustrious career in the soft drink industry that spanned more than four decades. He began that career in 1954 when he joined the Pepsi Cola Bottling Co. as an assistant driver. Mr. Maloney steadily rose through the ranks of Pepsi Cola in Cincinnati, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, and finally New York, where he was named Vice President of National Sales. In 1986, Mr. Maloney joined the Coca Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio as President, Chief Executive Officer. After a short stint in Akron, he moved to the Big Apple where he was named President and Chief Operating Officer of The Coca Cola Bottling Co. of New York, Inc. Mr. Maloney retired in 1996 as Chairman and CEO of the company. He resided in Juno Beach with his wife of fifty years, Jean Ann Maloney. He is also survived by his children, James T. & Rita Maloney of Acworth, GA, Kathleen Tebbe & her partner of nine years, Jim Quigley of Birmingham, MI., and Kevin Maloney of Jupiter, FL. He will be sorely missed by his six grandchildren, Allison, Shannon, Jennifer, Ryan, Thomas and Daniel along with their mother, Terry Maloney. He is also survived by his loving brother, Thomas Maloney of Cincinnati, OH. An avid golfer, Mr. Maloney was a member of Ballen Isle Country Club. He was also a Communicant of St. Patrick is Catholic Church, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Visitation will be 9AM-11AM Saturday, August 4, at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center St, Jupiter, FL. Mass of the Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11:30 AM Saturday at St. Patrick is Catholic Church, 13591 Prosperity Farms Rd, Palm Beach Gardens with Rev. Bernard Dooley as celebrant. Family requests donations in Mr. Maloney is memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

DEAR DIARY: My father is recent trip to the Big Apple -- one of the first times he is left our native Saskatchewan -- was complicated by his overwhelming fear of big-city germs. Therefore, though the heat was unbearable, Dad wore his gloves absolutely everywhere we went. At the Yankee game, at Zabar is, in the subway, when we had drinks outside Tavern on the Green -- as long as we were in public and no matter how I beseeched him, the thick insulated leather gloves never came off. Finally, my girlfriend gave it a shot. ''You know, Mr. Fass,'' she said, ''it is much more likely that you will get sick from wearing those gloves all day in this hot weather than if you took them off and exposed yourself to a little fresh air.'' Reluctantly, Dad took off his gloves. He was sick as a dog for two weeks. Mark Fass Dear Diary: Some years ago, I traveled from my then home in Los Angeles to New York and decided to visit the neighborhood in Williamsburg where I had grown up. I was on the subway en route when I realized that the man sitting across the aisle from me was George Wright, one of my high school teachers.

FRIEDMAN-Dr. Nathalie. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Nathalie Friedman, a cherished friend of the Jewish community and beloved sister of our former board member and longtime advocate, Rabbi Haskel Lookstein. A member of one of New York is leading Jewish families, Dr. Friedman was a brilliant scholar and remarkable person. During her career as a professor of sociology at Barnard College, she conducted meticulous research and produced prominent studies on the role of education on Jewish women, the family, and the community. We send our deepest sympathies to Dr. Friedman is husband, Israel; to her children, Steve and Sheira Schacter, Jessica and Allen Gribetz, Judy and Mark Tykocinski, and Naomi Schacter-Price and Jonathan Price; to her 18 grandchildren; to Rabbi Lookstein and his wife, Audrey; and to the entire family. Best Bet Since members of the Twin Shores Chorus heard a visiting quartet from Russia that 10 years ago toured the United States, they knew that barbershop singing had dedicated practitioners in that country. But they were surprised when more than 100 Russian singers and teachers and two octets, one from the Georgian Republic, showed up for a series of master classes that the Long Islanders and their colleagues from Manhattan, the Big Apple Chorus, gave last summer in St. Petersburg at the Third Annual St. Petersburg Barbershop Harmony Festival.

The rivalry between the PC and TV over which is destined to become the hearth of the home will take on new urgency on Monday when three prominent technology executives sketch out competing visions of their digital product lines. Steve Perlman, a former Apple hardware designer and co-founder of WebTV, will introduce a digital television set-top box as part of an alliance with EchoStar Communications, the satellite broadcaster. The partnership, which is to be announced on the opening day of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, will be the debut for Moxi Digital, the company Mr. Perlman founded in January 2000. Moxi was until recently named Rearden Steel Technologies.

Apple introduced an unorthodox version of its Mac personal computer today, seeking to refresh its once-popular three-year-old consumer model, which had begun to grow stale. The new PC, which features a translucent swiveling flat-panel display on top of a hemispherical pearl-white base, is certain to cause as much industry controversy and consternation as the original rounded Apple Mac, which was introduced in 1998.

NEDERLANDER-Harry Jay. The oldest of five brothers who run a theater empire that stretches from London to Los Angeles, died of cancer January 6, 2002 at his home in Rancho Mirage, California. He was 84. A Detroit native he also has a residence in Bloomfield Hills, MI. He was a Veteran of the US Army Ordinance Corps-WW II. Spearheaded by his father David Nederlander a showman and theater operator, Harry and his brothers owned or managed theaters in New York, Chicago, Cincinnati, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Detroit & London. A partner in the New York Yankees he is also on the Board at Beaumont Hospital in Michigan and Federated Investors in Pennsylvania. Lifetime honorary Chairman of the Board and past president of the Bloomfield Open Hunt Club, Bloomfield Hills, MI where he helped organize horse shows for many years. Also a member of the Bloomfield Hills Country Club and Morningside Country Club in Rancho Mirage where he was an avid golfer. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie; their children, Robert Wayne Nederlander, Harry Jay ''Skip'' Nederlander, Jr., Scott Nederlander (Dawn), Kathryn Breech Raft (Dr. Arnold) and W. Kimball Breech (Kristin); grandchildren; Taylor, Sarah, Chandra, Erin, Chad, Lauren, & Kristin; brothers, James Nederlander (Charlene), Frederick Nederlander (Betty), Joseph Nederlander (Carole) & Robert Nederlander (Gladys) and one sister Frances Nederlander Kohn. Memorial service Friday in suburban Detroit. No flowers please, family suggests memorials to Wayne State University Apple Award, 5104 Gullen Mass, Detroit, MI 48202 or Michigan Association For Children With Emotional Disorders (MACED), 15920 W. Twelve Mile Rd., Ste 201, Southfield, MI 48076. For information A.J. Desmond & Sons 800-294-5668

Zhang Yang is film tells the story of Jia Hongsheng, a rising Chinese movie star of the early 1990 is whose career was derailed by drug problems and mental illness. If Mr. Zhang is subject matter is, to some degree at least, quintessentially American, his approach to storytelling might be called Iranian. The role of Jia Hongsheng is played by the actor himself, and nearly all of the other characters in the film, from his parents (who are, like their son, professional actors) to his fellow inmates at a psychiatric hospital, likewise play themselves. This technique has been used, to extraordinary effect, by Iranian filmmakers like Abbas Kiarostami (most famously in "Close Up") and Samira Makhmalbaf (in "The Apple"). It sounds exploitive, but it is really the opposite. Somehow, inviting people to recreate moments of vulnerability and confusion affirms their dignity rather than stripping it away. — A. O. Scott

The stark, relentless images of exhausted travelers dragging themselves on foot through a treacherous mountain landscape in Samira Makhmalbaf is film evoke an indelible and ultimately moving vision of humanity buffeted by the elements and by international political tides. Ms. Makhmalbaf is film, which won the grand jury prize at the 2000 Cannes International Film Festival, offers as bare and stripped down a picture of life at the subsistence level as Iranian cinema, known for its austerity, has ever presented. All the more remarkable is that the filmmaker, the daughter of the widely acclaimed Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf ("Gabbeh," "Kandahar"), with whom she wrote the screenplay, was only 20 when she made "Blackboards." It is her second film, following "The Apple," and it made her the youngest director ever to have an official selection at Cannes when it was screened four years ago. — Stephen Holden

I have received some video clips, some of which I can open on my PC. What do the various format extensions mean, and how can I get my programs to open them? MPEG files seem to open with no problems, but I am stumped by AVI and WMV. And how does Apple QuickTime fit in? Is there a procedure for playing these mystery clips? A. Video clips come in many different formats, and not all multimedia software installed on the computer can play every type of format. To play the various clips, you should look at the three-letter extension at the end of the file name, which can help you choose the right player software.

INGALLS-Roscoe Jr. (Rocky), 1920 - 2003, died peacefully in Antigua, WI, on February 14, 2003. He was a resident of Bronxville, NY. As a graduate of Bowdoin College ('43, BS), Brunswick, ME, he subsequently attended the Naval Academy at Annapolis, MD, and was on active duty in the U.S. Navy Reserve from 1943 to 1946. As a lieutenant (gunnery officer) on the USS Lough DE586 he did duty in the Mediterranean and Pacific theatres during World War II. He was honorably discharged in 1955. He married Marjorie Davis in 1947. Children, Levana (Lynn Knight), Roscoe Cunningham III, Andrew Riegel. In 1946, he joined the firm of Ingalls & Snyder (IS), New York City, and became a partner in 1949. Later as senior partner he led IS through the difficulties of the 1970 is, until his retirement at age 79 on the 75th anniversary of IS. He was elected overseer at Bowdoin College in 1968 and became a trustee in 1973 and remained on the board till 1989. He was a member of the Securities Industries Association and the Chamber of Commerce; chairman of the NYSE Specialty Firms Advisory Committee (1986-1989). From 1966-1986 he was a board member of The Eastern Savings Bank which merged into The Apple Bank For Savings, where he continued to serve as a director until 1990. He held other board memberships at Apple Bancorp Inc. (1988-1990); Rexham Corporation (1971-1987) prior to which he was a director of Riegel Paper (1969) of which certain parts were converted into Rexham Corporation; Barclays Bank of New York (1974-1984); National Recreation and Park Association (1950-1977); Vice President of the National Recreation Foundation (1950-?). In 1983 he married Paula M.S. Verbeek. In Bronxville, he served on various committees at the Reformed Church. He was on the board of governors of Lawrence Hospital (19591966). He was the leading fund raiser to expand Lawrence Hospital with what is now known as the East Wing. Member of the Zoning Board of Appeals (1970-1974). Mr. Ingalls was a people is man and loved children. He was attracted to and by people spanning four generations: from his father is friends to his grandchildren and their friends. He is survived by his wife, Paula M.S. Ingalls, Bronxville, NY; sister, Shirley Ingalls Thackara, Carmel, CA; two sons, Andrew Ingalls, Dummerston, VT; Roscoe Ingalls III, Malvern, PA; daughter, Levana Fraval, Seattle, WA, and four grandchildren.

I often see question marks instead of text on Web pages that use Cyrillic or Arabic alphabets or the character sets of East Asian languages. Is there a way to read these Web pages in their native languages? A. Reading Web pages that use non-Latin alphabets is a lot easier than it used to be, thanks to improvements in browser software and computer operating systems. Most modern Web browsers, like Microsoft Internet Explorer and Apple is new Safari program, can easily handle the foreign alphabets. If you are using an older browser, updating your software might help.

FUCHSBERG-Abraham. Senior Partner of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg, a New York City plaintiff is personal injury firm, passed away on April 15, 2003, at the age of 87. He was one of five siblings (including the late Honorable Jacob Fuchsberg, a former Court of Appeals Judge), all of whom had worked together at the firm at one time or another. Abraham served the firm as its Senior Partner for over 25 years. After graduating Magna Cum Laude at the College of the City of New York, Mr. Fuchsberg (pronounced Fyooks-berg) served his country in the U.S. Army and was made an instructor at the Philippine Institute of Armed Forces. After his service Abraham obtained his law degree from St. John is University (1950), when he then joined his brother Jacob in establishing the firm of Fuchsberg & Fuchsberg. The firm became nationally recognized for its representation of the injured, and was the first firm in the United States to ever obtain a million dollar verdict for a personal injury victim. Mr. Fuchsberg devoted his life to the preservation of victims' rights. He served as President of the American Trial Lawyers Civil Justice Foundation, President of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association and President of the Big Apple Pothole Corporation. He was an active member of the Board of Governors for the American Trial Lawyers Association for 35 years, and was selected as a Charter Member of Atla is Presidents Club in 1999. Mr. Fuchsberg was a Patron Founder of the Trial Lawyers for Public Justice. Abraham Fuchsberg was Editor-InChief of the Trial Lawyers Quarterly until 2002, having served in an editorial capacity since 1964. He is the author of ''Modern New York Discovery,'' ''New York Evidence'' and ''Poetic Justice,'' a book of his poetry and insights. He also wrote numerous articles for the New York Law Journal. Mr. Fuchsberg was Associate Editor of the National Trial Lawyer, New York, and a Contributing Editor for Medical Malpractice Law and Strategy. As a public speaker he has addressed tens of thousands of listeners. Through the Abraham Fuchsberg Family Foundation, Mr. Fuchsberg provided over a quarter century is support for consumers, the injured, the needy, and many Jewish philanthropies, including the United Jewish Appeal. Abraham Fuchsberg was widely considered a brilliant legal strategist, a tough negotiator and a tireless supporter of the underpriviliged. In his own verse: ''We do not toil for fatted calves, but for the have-nots, not the haves. We speak for the lost, the lame, the dying, All who come to us for justice crying. To raise up all who may be falling-That indeed is our proud calling.'' He is survived by his loving wife Shirley Fuchsberg, daughters Irene Minkoff and Rita Fuchsberg, his grandson Jonathan Minkoff, and his granddaughter Sarah Minkoff. A memorial service is being planned, the details of which will be announced on the website: www.thenewyorkfirm.com In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to make a tax deductable donation to the Abraham Fuchsberg Family Foundation, 100 Church St, Suite 1800, NY, NY 10007.

Apple seems to have the future of online music in its hands for the moment. Its new service, iTunes Music Store, has been the first real success story in the long effort to sell music over the Internet. In just its first month of operation the service, by the company is estimate, has sold three million songs online, at 99 cents each. This is an impressive figure considering the limited access that music fans now have to the service. Less than 1 percent of the country is home computers are Macintoshes that are compatible with the iTunes Music Store, and only a fraction of those have a broadband connection to the Internet. But it would not be an online success story without a complicating twist. That complication came this week when the specter of the music industry, which has been publicly supportive of iTunes, began to loom over Apple. The success of iTunes, after all, depends on cooperation from the music business, which controls the songs that iTunes wants in its collection. Apparently trying to stay in the record industry is good graces, iTunes removed a service it had previously offered customers. Called Rendezvous, the service enabled listeners and their friends to access one another is music and listen to it -- but not download it -- from any computers. Hackers, however, had figured out how to download the music as well, creating programs with names like iLeach and iSlurp. So on Tuesday Apple sent out an update for its iTunes software, disabling Rendezvous and limiting music access to a user is local network at home or at work.

INSTANT messaging certainly has its charms. You and a conversation partner on the Internet type back and forth in a narrow window, your quips scrolling up the screen like a hastily written script. The fact that you can not see or hear the other person is either the best feature or the worst, depending on how self-conscious you are and how your hair looks. Better start combing. Last week both Microsoft and Apple incorporated audio and video into their popular chat programs, now called MSN Messenger 6 and iChat AV. You can download them free at messenger.msn.com or apple.com/ichat, respectively, as part of a public beta test -- a software company is way of saying, ''Sure they are buggy, but what do you want for free?''

I enjoy books on CD is and would like to listen to them on my iPod. I can import the CD is into my iTunes music software and create MP3 files of the readings, but I do not see any way to bookmark a file when I stop listening to it in my iPod. Does the iPod offer a bookmark function? A. The iPod, Apple is portable player for digital music files, has a built-in bookmark function that can hold your place in an audio book, but the feature works only with files in the Audible format. Audible files, which have a file extension of .aa, include audio books, radio programs and other spoken-word content and are available at www.audible.com. The Audible bookmark feature does not typically work with MP3 files, including those you make yourself from audio book CD is. But if you press the iPod is pause button and allow the device to go into sleep mode, it will usually resume playing the audio file at the point where you left off. This is not a wholly reliable feature because buttons can be pushed accidentally, and switching between songs or connecting the iPod to a computer will cause it to lose your place in an audio book. Another way to return to your place in an audio file is to note the time code displayed on the iPod is screen when you press Stop. When you resume listening, the recording will begin to play from the beginning. Press the round Select button in the middle of the iPod is scroll wheel, then rotate the wheel to advance quickly through the file to return to the time you noted. Pressing the iPod is Next/Fast Forward button while a file is playing will also enable you to advance it quickly through a song or audio book. Audible.com has a large collection of content to download at a variety of prices. Audible files mesh well with Apple is iTunes music program for Macintosh and can also be used with the new Windows iPod with the latest iPod software and Audible is AudibleManager software (www.audible.com/software). Is there a place on the Web that offers free downloads of electronic books in the public domain? A. More than 6,200 complete electronic books are available for downloading from the library of Project Gutenberg (gutenberg.net). The collection includes Shakespeare is plays, ''Frankenstein'' by Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley, a selection of Tarzan novels by Edgar Rice Burroughs and thousands of other literary works. Most of the books and electronic texts available from Project Gutenberg date from before 1923, so their copyrights have expired. They come in the form of plain text files that are usually compressed in the Zip format for faster downloading. Once you download a book, you can read it on a computer in any text-editing or word-processing program, print it out or transfer it to a personal organizer or other device that can display text files. Project Gutenberg accepts donations of money and time from volunteers who are willing to type in or proofread additions to the collection. Microsoft Word has the largest share of the word processing market over all, but not within the legal profession, where Corel is WordPerfect is the leader. What features make WordPerfect more attractive to lawyers and their staffs? A. Several factors are probably involved. WordPerfect became a standard program in many law offices back in the days of DOS, and Corel produces a version geared specifically to the needs of legal word-processing. Although Word pulled ahead of WordPerfect in terms of market share as the Windows operating system took hold in the 1990 is, some lawyers find that WordPerfect handles footnotes and endnotes far more reliably. WordPerfect is Reveal Codes feature, which allows you to see precisely how text is formatted, also has many devotees. A Web site called WordPerfect vs. Word (www.wpvsword.com) devotes itself to meticulous comparison of the features of each program is latest version. J.D.BIERSDORFER

HOELTERHOFF -- Olga Christina, (nee Goertz). Born May 14, 1912 in Riga in Latvia, died December 17, 2003 in Valley Cottage, NY. Her long and complicated life reflected the tragedy of the Baltic States. Driven from her beloved home in Jurmala by Hitler and Stalin, displaced and often ill, she survived through tenacity, intelligence, and compromise. For 45 years, America offered her a bewildering refuge where she cherished her small house, many pets and her only child, and freely expressed her views, most recently on shooting bears and invading Iraq in a selection of five languages. Her curiosity, love of the arts (especially the Metropolitan Museum) and memories of Riga, Hamburg, Milan, Berlin, Saloniki, Venice and Franco Corelli are lovingly treasured by her makeshift family: Manuela, Francesca, Marilyn, Sheila, Irene, Margaret, Hilda, Eddie, Pince Pince, Sugar, Emma, Minnie, Sparkle, Tosca, Cosimo. And, from another realm, her husband Heinz Alfons Martin Hoelterhoff and her mutt Apple.

ONYAN--Blaine Wellington, of Fort Lee, died on February 11, 2004, at the age of 92. Blaine, beloved husband of Edith Hufman Onyan, liked to call himself the ''an upstate Apple Knocker.'' He was born in Clinton, NY and raised in Oriskany Falls. He was especially proud of his service in the US Army during World War II, a draftee rising to Captain over his 52 months. For many years he was a sales engineer with the Cyclone Fence Division of US Steel. After retiring he was associated with Royal Guard Fence Company in Westbury and acted as consultant on fencing for New York City Parks Department. Besides his wife, he leaves nieces Susan Skogerson, Patricia Reske; nephews Kenneth and Howard Gould. Visiting will be Friday 3:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 p.m. at the Frank Patti and Kenneth Mikatarian Funeral Home, 327 Main Street ''opposite the Fort Lee Library.'' Religious service Saturday at 10:00 a.m. Burial in Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY at 12:30 p.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Children is Aid Society of New York or the charity of your choice. For further information: www.pattiandmikatarian .com or 201-944-0100.

Dr. Antonia Elizabeth Stephen and Andrew Rossi Kirk were married yesterday in Woods Hole, Mass. The Rev. Bruce Teague, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph is Church. She graduated magna cum laude from Brown and received her medical degree from Harvard.

Are there digital audio players that support not only MP3, WAV and Apple Lossless file formats, but also SHN and FLAC files? A. Digital audio file formats abound on the Internet, and two types that are becoming more common as a result of legal online sharing of concert recordings are Shorten, or SHN, and Free Lossless Audio Codec, FLAC. While you can usually find a software program to play the files on your desktop computer, finding a portable audio player that can understand some of the lesser-known formats can still be a bit of a challenge.

WILSON--David Anthony III. Age twenty-one, died on Wednesday, September 22, 2004, in the Adirondack Park near Wells, NY. Majoring in computer science, David was a senior at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, NY. David attended the Episcopal School and Trinity School in New York City. After three years at Brunswick School in Greenwich, CT, he attended Gould Academy in Bethel, Maine. He graduated high school from The Pomfret School in Pomfret, CT. David was an expert skier, and an avid photographer. He enjoyed all types of music and loved movies. Dave educated himself on topics such as artificial intelligence, economics, and politics by reading, research, and debate. He was an ardent Apple proponent. His favorite author was Noam Chomsky. He is survived by his parents, Ann and David Wilson, Jr. of New Canaan, CT, his sister, Elizabeth Wilson of New York City, maternal grandparents Lt. Col. George Gaumond, USAF (retired), and Madeline Gaumond of Bradenton, FL, and paternal grandfather David Wilson of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan on September 30th at 3 p.m. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: American Civil Liberties Union (www. aclu.org) or Heifer International (www.heifer.org).

ATT, the long-distance provider, said yesterday that it was testing the open-source Linux operating system as an alternative to the Microsoft Windows operating system, which runs on the company is 70,000 personal computers. ATT is also reviewing an operating system from Apple. The company said it had no immediate plans to replace the Windows software, which is used on about 95 percent of all PC is, but it is weighing the reliability, security, productivity and cost of the various systems. Linux is moving into the desktop market, but so far it has been focused more on software for servers. Ken Belson (NYT)

Apple says its fourth-quarter profit more than doubled because of continued strong sales of iPod music players, beating Wall Street estimates by wide margin; net income was $106 million in fourth quarter ended Sept 25, compared with profit of $44 million in last year is fourth quarter; revenue rose 37 percent, to $2.35 billion, from $1.72 billion year ago; chief executive Steve Jobs comments

INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Pentagon Opens Review Of Formerly Dismissed Case The Pentagon is reviewing whether to reopen an inquiry into the case of four Iraqis who said they were abused in January at an American base in Iraq. A Defense Department spokesman said the decision was not influenced by the recent release of two reports on detainee abuse. A10 Prime Minister Ayad Allawi warned insurgents in Falluja that they must hand over foreign militants or face a military operation. His ultimatum came as a group posted an additional video showing two men being beheaded, and six American soldiers were reported killed in insurgent attacks. A10 NATO defense ministers pledged to speed the deployment of 300 trainers to Iraq by the end of the year, a program intended to field more Iraqi security forces who can help safeguard the elections in January. Some officials warned of delays in persuading NATO members to volunteer troops for the mission. A8 German officials reaffirmed their policy of not contributing troops to the American-led force in Iraq and rejected speculation that the policy might change in the foreseeable future. Germany has embarked on a program to train Iraqi police recruits outside of Iraq, but it has refused to send troops of its own. A11 Four Militants Killed in Gaza The Israeli military killed four Palestinian militants as troops pushed into another town in the northern Gaza Strip, extending a two-week-old operation aimed at silencing Palestinian rocket fire. A5 Taiwan is Secret Nuclear Tests Taiwan may have carried out plutonium separation experiments in the mid-1980 is, taking its nuclear program a step further than previously disclosed. That program has since been abandoned, but the disclosure comes at a time when several countries have been scrutinized for undisclosed nuclear activity. A6 NATIONAL A16-26 Talk of Domestic Policy Dominates Final Debate President Bush and Senator John Kerry battled over the state of health care, the fairness of Mr. Bush is tax cuts and whether they would appoint justices who would uphold the right to abortion. The candidates offered a stark contrast in their views of virtually every major domestic issue, particularly Mr. Bush is stewardship of the economy. A25 Reporter Held in Contempt A federal district judge held a Time magazine White House correspondent in contempt of court, threatening him with up to 18 months in jail if he refused to testify before a grand jury investigating the disclosure of an intelligence officer is identity. A16 SCIENCE/HEALTH Fight for Flu Vaccine Heats Up Clinics offering the flu vaccine are being mobbed by desperate vaccine seekers. All four have been caused by Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, a brain disease that afflicts one in a million people a year. About three hours' drive north of San Francisco, the Anderson Valley is to Napa what the North Fork of Long Island is to the Hamptons: smart and blissfully unpretentious, the land that yuppies forgot. Thanks to its remote location and a local economy favoring the barter system, this is where you can trade a few cases of your vineyard is pinot noir for midwife services. The valley is neighboring ' notowns'' -- Boonville and Philo (combined population: 1,400) -- offer food and wine with a rich-hippie flourish. It is the ideal place to drop out and fill up for a weekend. Some local attractions: The Apple Farm 18501 Greenwood Road, Philo; (707)895-2461; go to www.philoapplefarm.com. In 1994, Sally and Don Schmitt were tired of running their Yountville restaurant, so they sold it to Thomas Keller and joined Sally is daughter on this orchard, offering weekend cooking classes and a low-key inn. Navarro Vineyards 5601 Highway 128, Philo; (707)895-3686; go to www.navarrowine.com. Philo is favorable growing conditions, combined with Navarro is sustainable business (pickers get health insurance), have yielded 12 varieties of award-winning wines. Available only at select restaurants (like Daniel and Union Square Cafe) and by mail order; you can also sample and buy at the vineyard. Lazy Creek Vineyards 4741 Highway 128, Philo; (707)895-3632. Call ahead, or, if the gate is open, drive in for big wines made on a small scale, like an oak- and butter-free chardonnay and unfiltered, dry-farmed (i.e., intense) pinot noir. Libby is Restaurant 8651 Highway 128, Philo; (707)895-2646. This Mexican restaurant dishes up scrumptious carnitas, mole enchiladas and chile rellenos. Not to be missed. The Boonville Hotel 14050 Highway 128, Boonville; (707)895-2210. Some locals roll their eyes at the zippy redesign of this hotel and restaurant, but guests certainly do not mind. The chef, John Schmitt, who grew up cooking with his mom, Sally, at the French Laundry, dreams up lush California comfort food. On Saturdays from May to October the farmer is market takes over the parking lot. Boonville General Store 17810-B Farrer Lane, Boonville; (707)895-9477. Do not let the down-home name fool you: this shop offers sophisticated soups, salads, grilled sandwiches and sometimes homemade ice cream. The store also stocks local wines, olive oils and kitchen and garden tools. Christine Muhlke

After a two-week tussle between the charity Band Aid Trust and Apple, iTunes users in Britain will now be able to download the new recording of ''Do They Know It is Christmas?,'' the pop song for African relief. The song had been unavailable on the British iTunes site because Apple had refused to charge the £1.49 (about $2.85) that Band Aid wanted; all other songs on British iTunes are sold for 79 pence (about $1.50). The charity refused to back down, and yesterday Apple said it would offer the song at 79 pence, and pay the remaining 70 pence out of its own pocket. HEATHER TIMMONS

I have some songs that play fine with the iTunes program, but when I look for the song files on my hard drive, I can not find them. How can I find these files? A. Is there a major loss of sound quality when tracks are converted and transferred from a CD to a portable player? A. To store hundreds or thousands of songs on one device, most digital music players, from the Apple iPod to Creative is Zen Micro to the Rave-MP Amp, typically use tracks that have been extracted, encoded and compressed from files on original compact discs. During the process, large CD tracks -- which can be about 40 to 50 megabytes per song -- are crunched down into files of about 4 or 5 megabytes to make them more manageable.

In 2002 and 2003, Fiona Apple recorded what would have been her third album, ''Extraordinary Machine.'' Its producer, Jon Brion, has said that Ms. Apple is label, Sony Music is Epic Records, shelved the album because it did not hear potential hit singles. An Epic spokeswoman said, ''Fiona has not yet delivered her next album.'' Lately, what purports to be the full album, 11 songs, has been leaked onto the Internet, where -- despite the efforts of Sony is legal department -- a simple search will find multiple sources of downloads. The album is an oddball gem. Its producer, Mr. Brion, is fond of instruments that huff and plink and wheeze, as he showed in his soundtrack for ''I [heart] Huckabees.'' Epic may have been discomfited that Ms. Apple is collaboration with him does not sound anything like what is on the radio now. As a songwriter, she is the same Fiona Apple who sold millions of copies of her first two albums; she is still sultry and sullen, obsessing in detail over why her romances went wrong and teetering between regret and revenge. Her vocals smolder like torch songs, then boil over with rage and accusations. But this time, the music does not always mope with her. The album sets the 21st century aside. The beats are often waltzes and oom-pahs, not hiphop or punk; the arrangements are full of cellos, horns, bells and vintage keyboards. Ms. Apple is piano and voice are still at the center of the music, but now orchestras and show bands sprout around her, adding layers of whimsy and artifice. Ms. Apple has always placed herself somewhere between confession and entertainment, but in songs like ''Window'' or ''Better Version of Me,'' the carnival bounces and mock-Hollywood glitz put a cartoonish frame around her traumas, giving them a brand-new perspective. Had it been released, ''Extraordinary Machine'' would have been a fine counterbalance to a pop moment full of monolithic, self-righteous sincerity. As it stands, mysteriously leaked and proliferating, the album is an object lesson in how an Internet that is not controlled by copyright holders can set artistic expression free. JON PARELES

Maximizing the Life Of a Mac is Battery I use my PowerBook G4 at home and on the road, and I would like to maximize the life of its rechargeable battery. Is it best to leave it plugged into a power source at home, or to leave it unplugged so it can discharge and then recharge it as necessary? A. Apple does not recommend leaving the PowerBook plugged in all the time with its lithium-ion battery connected because the internal chemistry can stagnate, which may shorten battery life. Unplugging the laptop and working from the battery once a month or so helps to discharge the stored energy and gets those electrons moving. The company also recommends that you calibrate your laptop is battery every few months. Laptop batteries contain microprocessors that tell the computer how much of a charge is left, but they can get out of sync. This causes the computer to give incorrect information about the charge status. Calibration helps the battery and computer communicate more accurately.

I DON'T think that politics has paralyzed Gotham is once vaunted ability to get big things done. At this very moment, New York is driving City Water Tunnel No. 3 through bedrock 60-odd stories beneath Manhattan, one of the most colossal construction projects on earth. Nor (happily enough) did every enterprise proposed in the Good Old Days come to fruition -- like the proposal in 1893 to tear down City Hall, or Mayor William Gaynor is suggestion in 1910 to ram a new street through Midtown between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

THE inability to get large public projects off the ground in New York reflects less a lack of ambition than a failure to come to consensus over the role of government in land use. There is a tendency to criticize any public investment in projects that are not absolutely needed. We take for granted our great public works, like Central Park and the Public Library, as if they were handed down by Moses. Actually, they were created by real people with precious dollars, public and private (including some by another Moses, Robert). These are our temples.

New York has never received this award because, apart from a handful of great old buildings, it has had little to show of architectural innovation for the past 50 years. Great architecture has rarely been a goal of our political decision makers, as we have witnessed in recent weeks.

NO project would yield more tangible benefits for our region than Moynihan Station. As a child, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, my late father, sold newspapers and shined shoes in the old Penn Station. As senator, he secured nearly $1 billion in federal, state and city funds to rebuild the station in the landmark James Farley Post Office.

HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city is 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow. WHETHER or not one supported building the West Side stadium -- or even the city is Olympic bid, which I did -- the problems that ultimately killed the project underscore the difficulty of doing any kind of large-scale building in New York. But great cities, in the end, are defined by their ability to move past politics and local issues to create the unexpected.

All told, we are talking about 40 to 50 blocks south of Javits that extend over the rail yards and down to 28th Street. My proposal would be to use five of those blocks to expand the Javits center to 3 million square feet, from 800,000. Here is why.

HAVE New Yorkers lost their chutzpah? The demise of the proposed Jets stadium on the Far West Side (and the attendant blow to the city is 2012 Olympic hopes), along with the politically induced inertia at the World Trade Center site, has led to speculation that the Big Apple is turning into a crab apple. So the Op-Ed Page approached several prominent New Yorkers with a question: If the city wants to start thinking big again, where should it start? Their suggestions follow. IT is much easier to defeat something in New York City than to build something. With that in mind, we should consider whether we want the easy way out or if we can accept a challenge. New Yorkers have been known for their energy, their strength and, especially in the past few years, for their courage. Maybe we are just worn out after pulling together so well after Sept. 11, 2001. It is been a haul. So maybe we just want to sit back and let things take care of themselves -- elsewhere.

When Kevin Callahan started offering classical guitar lessons over an Internet video link, he wanted the sound to be as close as possible to being in the same room. After experimenting, he built a system that channeled three guitars, a microphone, and an orchestral synthesizer through a professional mixing board to his Macintosh. From there, he blended the sound with Apple is GarageBand software before sending it out over the Internet. ''It is not necessary,'' he explained a bit nonchalantly, ''but it gives me quite a bit of flexibility.''

Many Web sites index radio programs. But Radio Time (www.radiotime.com) does more: it supplies software for recording shows either from Web-based streaming audio or over the airwaves with computers attached to a U.S.B. antenna. In effect, it offers radio listeners a variation of what TiVo recorders give television viewers. There are various ways to use the site, which collects programming data for radio stations using software and human listeners. Listeners who do not wish to register can use the service as a program guide and a link to about 50 stations at no cost. People willing to pay $39 a year get access to about 36,000 indexed stations and get software that can record selected broadcasts. Those broadcasts, in turn, can be transferred to an Apple iPod or many other portable music players.

Do I have to use America Online is software to download my AOL mail, or can I use the same e-mail program I use for my other mail accounts? A. Although America Online once required that you use its own software to send and receive mail from your AOL account, you can now use a standard e-mail program like Outlook or Eudora to manage your AOL mail. The e-mail program you use needs to support the IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol) system for handling e-mail, which is different from the POP (Post Office Protocol) used by many mail programs. Some mail programs like Apple Mail can handle both IMAP and POP.

Lisa Ann Sanditz and Timothy Michael Selin Davis, both artists, were married yesterday. Canyon Kenev Blue Yarrow Steinzig, a minister of the Universal Life Church and a friend of the couple, officiated at Apple Barn Farm in Linlithgo, N.Y. Ms. Sanditz, 31, is keeping her name. A contemporary landscape painter, she is represented by the CRG Gallery in New York, where her work will be shown in September. She graduated from Macalester College in St. Paul and received a master is degree in painting from Pratt Institute. She is a daughter of JoAnn Sanditz and Theodore Sanditz of St. Louis. Her father is an independent broker of employee benefits and insurance in St. Louis. Her mother is a grant writing consultant and the president of the board of the women is society of Washington University in St. Louis.

Apple added new utility on Tuesday to the device that gave podcasts their name. It made available a version of its iTunes software designed for subscribing to podcasts, audio recordings that can be downloaded to an iPod or other music player for portable listening. The company also announced that it was merging its iPod and iPod Photo product lines, creating a single line of MP3 players that all feature color displays with the ability to view album artwork, photos and slide shows as well as play music.

As Errol Rose made preparations on Monday to bury his 15-year-old son, Christopher, who was killed last week in Brooklyn during a fight over an iPod, he received a telephone call from a stranger. The Standard & Poor is 500-stock index closed yesterday at its highest level in four years, after good earnings news from Apple, lower-than-expected inflation in June and stronger-than-expected retail sales. An additional lift came from a sharp drop in the price of crude oil, which fell 3.7 percent to a price below $58 a barrel.

STOLER--Barney. Of Sunrise, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away gently and peacefully in his sleep on July 14, 2005. Barney enjoyed over 90 glorious years, 62 years of which he shared with his wife, Jean. Barney was a devoted and adored father of his loving daughter Marcia (William) Birnbaum who was with him as he entered into his peaceful new world. He leaves a family legacy including three grandsons, Brett (Melissa) Gottlieb, Jamie (Michelle) Gottlieb, and Scott Gottlieb, and four lovable great-grandchildren, Shawna, Kaleb, Devin and Joshua. Barney was the apple of his mother is eye, and his brothers and sisters looked up to him even though he was the baby of his family. His business accomplishments were highlighted as a respected CPA member of AICPA and NYSSCPA, Treasurer of Big Apple and Waldbaums Supermarkets, and was instrumental in their being listed on the NYSE. He will truly be missed by all those who had the great fortune to know Barney. Services at Star of David, Lauderdale, FL, 1:45pm

Robust retail sales and a surge in industrial production also appeared to give investors a signal to buy.

On June 29, Apple released a new version of its popular iTunes software that allows users to download podcasts, which are audio files that can be automatically loaded onto computers and devices like iPods. In the two days after the software is release, Apple said users signed up for more than a million podcast subscriptions (the company would not release the exact number), a figure far greater than the total number of podcast users in 2004, as estimated by the Diffusion Group, a research firm.

With its library of sound samples and easy-to-use interface, the GarageBand program from Apple has been helping Macintosh mavens create and mix their own musical compositions since it was introduced early last year. With the M-Audio iControl device, people who prefer a physical recording console now have plenty of knobs to twirl in front of the screen instead of on it. The iControl connects to the Mac through a U.S.B. port and includes buttons that correspond to many of GarageBand is onscreen controls for actions like play, stop and record. A master volume switch and a jog wheel for dialing back to a precise point in the recording are also within easy reach.

It was with great fanfare that Hewlett-Packard announced in January 2004 that it would begin selling Apple is digital music player, the iPod, in a deal that was cast as a major step forward for both companies. Earlier this week, however, Hewlett-Packard quietly retreated from that deal when it informed Apple it would stop selling the iPod. A spokeswoman for Apple suggested that the move hardly mattered given how minor a role Hewlett has played in the spreading popularity of the iPod.

Four pay phones sit on the corner of West 34th Street and 10th Avenue, two on the southeast corner and two on the northwest, and on a sultry afternoon last week a steady stream of callers fed them a steady stream of quarters. By the looks of it, most of the callers were not aware of two other phones nearby, on the northeast corner, that do not strictly qualify as pay phones. The phones are free for calls shorter than four minutes, part of a campaign by a small communications company called Popa Media Big Apple, which has installed 47 payless phones around the city. The company makes money by selling snappy advertisements placed next to the phones that it hopes callers cannot help but notice.

In horse racing parlance, there are useful horses, very nice ones and champions. By romping to an effortless nine-and-a-half-length victory over four rivals Sunday in the Grade Go For Wand Handicap, Ashado showed that once a champion can translate into always a champion. Last year, Ashado, a daughter of Saint Ballado, won five of eight starts, including the Breeders' Cup Distaff, to be named the best 3-year-old filly in the nation. When she opened the year with lackluster performances in the Apple Blossom Handicap and the Pimlico Breeders Cup Distaff Handicap, many figured she was just a precocious filly who failed to develop and relegated to the ' havery nice horse'' bin.

For decades one of Silicon Valley is favorite Zen questions has been, ''How many buttons should a computer mouse have?'' Apple is co-founder and chief executive, Steve Jobs, once said that one was the obvious answer because that made it impossible to push the wrong button.

Plunked amid a phalanx of ornate buildings on Fifth Avenue -- structures with classic Greek columns, cast-iron arches, filigreed cresting and intricate friezes -- is a two-story stub of a building that has preservationists gnashing their teeth at the Applempany. The preservationists do not particularly want the decidedly unremarkable, 3,550-square-foot building at 136 Fifth Avenue, between 18th and 19th Streets, to be preserved. They are not demanding that its proposed replacement mirror the florid style of its environs.

Cnooc Withdraws Its $18.5 Billion Unocal Bid, Blocked by Both Resentment and Bitterness Cnooc, the Chinese oil company, said it was withdrawing its $18.5 billion offer to buy Unocal, an oil company that is likely now to be acquired by Chevron and remain in American hands. The pullback underscores the resentment and bitterness that has formed in China and the United States over the effort to buy what some consider a strategic asset: extensive oil reserves in Asia. To Buy a Mac Now Or Wait Awhile I want to buy a new Mac now, but was wondering if I should wait until the new Intel-based versions appear. Is there any reason to wait? A. Apple is recent announcement that it was changing the processors inside its Macintosh computers means some big changes when the company switches to Intel-based chips from the current PowerPC processors made by I.B.M. and Motorola. Apple plans to release some Macs with Intel processors starting in 2006, and hopes to have most new Macs running the chips by 2007. Such a change typically means that programs and software written to run on one type of processor must be rewritten or modified to work on a different processor. Some companies may create a version of a program that runs on both PowerPC and Intel chips, while others may sell the versions separately.

A health department inspector was attacked by a man yesterday during a visit to a day camp in the Longwood section, the police said. The inspector, a 26-year-old woman who was not identified by the authorities, arrived at the New Apple Family and Community Service Day Camp, a licensed camp, at 726 Prospect Avenue, about 8:30 a.m. She was admitted by Donald McKinnon, 54, who began punching, choking and biting her, the police said. The inspector fought him off, and he fled. The inspector was taken to a hospital and treated, the police said. Officers used bloodhounds to track Mr. McKinnon, who was arrested a few hours later at a nearby building. Last night, charges against him were pending, the police said. Sid Dinsay, a spokesman for the health department, said he did not know if the inspection was routine or the result of a complaint. He said day camps are inspected once a year. Michelle Donnell (NYT)

Poet Rebuffs Laura Bush Protesting the war in Iraq, the poet Sharon Olds, winner of a National Book Critics Circle Award and professor of writing at New York University, has rebuffed an invitation from Laura Bush, below, the first lady, to attend the fifth National Book Festival on the National Mall in Washington on Saturday. Noting that the event, sponsored by the Library of Congress, includes a dinner at the library and a breakfast at the White House, Ms. Olds, in a letter on the Web site of The Nation (thenation.com/doc/20051010/olds), said she found the invitation appealing. ''But I could not face the idea of breaking bread with you,'' she wrote in a letter to Mrs. Bush. ''I knew that if I sat down to eat with you, it would feel to me as if I were condoning what I see to be the wild, highhanded actions of the Bush administration. So many Americans who had felt pride in our country now feel anguish and shame, for the current regime of blood, wounds and fire. I thought of the clean linens at your table, the shining knives and the flames of the candles, and I could not stomach it.''
