TODAY'S theme is elegant underdogs: the devices or solutions that do not lead their markets but are in many ways more admirable than the ones that do. For years the Apple Macintosh has defined this category. Indeed, the Mac is business history illustrates important changes in the role of the tech also-ran. From the mid-1980 is through the late 1990 is -- a period that started with the widening use of Windows and ran through the widening use of the Internet -- the pressures toward standardization created not just market leaders but also all-dominating market leviathans. Consider word-processing software: through the 80 is and early 90 is, there were a dozen contenders. Now, for practical purposes, there is only Microsoft Word.
Fiona Apple is new vocals are even more assured in her magnificent third album. Also, new releases from Franz Ferdinand, Twista and Sinead Connor.

With her low, melancholy voice and the tortured conscience of her lyrics, Fiona Apple never seemed cut out for comedy. But in six years between albums, Ms. Apple, 28, has grown into a wry self-consciousness. Her romances are still a shambles, and she painstakingly splits the blame between her lovers and herself. Yet there is a new layer of perspective on her magnificent third album, ''Extraordinary Machine'' (Epic/Clean Slate). ''I think he let me down when he did not disappoint me,'' she admits in ''Get Him Back.'' As she plunges into her latest miseries, her music finds something droll in the cycle of love and betrayal. She does it with anachronism. Her music looks back as far as the 1920 is and 30 is, with her piano giving the songs a music-hall bounce, while her lyrics are unmistakably modern: confessional, self-doubting, occasionally awkward and determinedly personal. ''My method is uncertain/It is a mess, but it is working,'' she sings in ''Please Please Please,'' which could be a reproach to a music business that urges, ''Give us something familiar.''

There are many pocketsize digital music players available, but they fall into two groups: Apple is iPod products and everything else. That split, rooted in technology as well as style, poses a challenge for music lovers who want to upgrade their devices. IPods, the most popular music players with more than 70 percent of the American market, can play MP3 music files, a popular digital audio compression format. But for the most part, Apple steers its customers to songs in another format, called Advanced Audio Codec (AAC), which most non-Apple devices cannot play.

Most of the 20 million people who regularly listen to Internet radio use a desktop, laptop or hand-held computer. SoundBridge Radio from Roku Labs (www.rokulabs.com) aims to remove the computer from the equation. This 70-watt tabletop stereo connects directly to radio stations that offer streaming talk and music. The radio, which needs a Wi-Fi network to communicate, is expected to be out next month and to sell for $400, with a $50 discount for orders placed before Oct. 31. It comes with presets for 50 popular online stations. Listeners can browse for other stations by genre if Apple is iTunes software is running on a computer on the network, or they can manually enter station addresses through a Web browser.

PODCASTING, technology experts have predicted, will democratize audio entertainment, much as Web blogs have leveled the playing field for print-media outlets. Talk radio shows and music that does not have to pass the muster of corporate-owned radio stations can be downloaded to portable MP3 players, often free. And with the iPod Nano, the latest entry in the digital music-player market, Apple has sparked further excitement about podcasting.

Microsoft finally put its antitrust troubles in the United States behind it yesterday by agreeing to pay RealNetworks $761 million to settle a lawsuit. The two former enemies agreed to forge a partnership that promises to heighten the competitive pressure on the dominant company in digital music, Apple. The announcement reflects how much the landscape in the software and digital media markets has changed in the last few years. The strategies and interests of Microsoft and RealNetworks have shifted as well, making them allies.

Apple Selects a Worldwide Sales Executive To Become Its Chief Operating Officer Apple has named Tim Cook, the company is executive vice president for worldwide sales and operations, as chief operating officer. Mr. Cook, left, who took over day-to-day operations during chief executive Steve Jobs' recovery from cancer surgery last year, will essentially become the No.2 person at Apple. ''Tim has been doing this job for over two years now, and it is high time we officially recognized it with this promotion,'' Mr. Jobs said in a statement. Mr. Cook, 44, will continue to overseeing worldwide operations and leading the Macintosh division, and will work with Mr. Jobs and the executive team to lead Apple is overall business, Apple said. The company also said Jon Rubinstein, head of the iPod unit, will retire March 31 and be succeeded by Tony Fadell, vice president for iPod engineering. (AP) Pension Agency Objects to Airline is Reorganization Plan The government agency that insures corporate pensions has objected to United Airlines' reorganization plan, saying in court documents that the carrier has changed a deal covering the termination of its pensions. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said in a filing that the airline is disclosure statement, which details its financial model, is ''unconfirmable.'' United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, must get bankruptcy court approval of the statement before asking creditors to vote on restructuring. The agency complained that the plan was inconsistent with a settlement the parties reached last spring for the airline to turn its pensions over to the government. (Reuters) Medical Device Maker Posts a Quarterly Loss Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had lost ground to its only medical device rival in the lucrative market for drug-coated heart stents, reporting a $269 million third-quarter loss and slowing sales of a stent that provided big profits last year. The performance, hurt by a $598 million expense for a legal settlement, fell short of company is projection and Wall Street is expectations. Boston Scientific executives said in a conference call with analysts that its Taxus stent has lost market share to the Cypher stent made by Johnson & Johnson is Cordis Corporation. The company, based in Natick, Mass., said it lost 33 cents a share and the results compared with a profit of $258 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to $1.51 billion. (AP) Bank of America is Purchase of MBNA Advances Delaware is banking commissioner yesterday approved the proposed $35 billion acquisition of MBNA by the Bank of America Corporation, moving the buyout of the world is largest independent credit card issuer one step closer to completion. The approval of the Delaware banking commissioner, Robert Glen, was required because MBNA is based in Wilmington, Del. Bank of America is based in Charlotte, N.C. (AP) Justice Department Approves Software Merger Adobe Systems said late Thursday that the Justice Department had approved its $3.4 billion acquisition of Macromedia. Adobe and Macromedia, two of the largest providers of graphic design software, must wait for several European jurisdictions to approve the deal before it can close. Adobe is Illustrator and Macromedia is Freehand are two of the leading products for vector graphics illustration, a term for drawings that are stored as collections of points and objects instead of pixels. A combined company would also own a substantial part of the market for Web site-building tools. (AP) Profit Rises 21 Percent at Insurer UnitedHealth The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation is largest health insurance companies, reported a 21 percent increase in third-quarter profit on membership gains and lower-than-expected medical costs. The company forecast profit growth would continue through 2006 at an annual rate of at least 15 percent. UnitedHealth predicted a Medicare prescription drug benefit would add 2 million to 3 million members to its rolls next year, potentially increasing 2006 earnings by 5 cents a share. UnitedHealth said it expected to complete its acquisition of PacifiCare Health by year-end or early in 2006. UnitedHealth said its third-quarter profit rose to $842 million, or 64 cents a share, from $698 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $11.3 billion. (Reuters) Bush Seeks End to Lumber Trade Dispute With Canada President Bush told the Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin yesterday that it was time to find a solution to a long-running trade fight between the two countries over softwood lumber. A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Martin spoke by telephone for about 20 minutes, and trade was a major part of their discussion. Mr. Martin criticized the United States government last week for its position on trade in lumber, saying Washington was ignoring a North American Free Trade Agreement ruling against United States duties on Canadian softwood lumber. (Reuters) Developer is Bid for British Grocer Is Accepted A billionaire property developer, Robert Tchenguiz, and two partners won the right to buy Somerfield, a British grocer, for £1.08 billion ($1.9 billion) to gain control of its real estate. The bid, 197 pence for each share in Somerfield, was accepted, Anthony Cardew, a spokesman for Somerfield, said yesterday. The investor group includes Tchenguiz, Apax Partners Worldwide and Barclays Capital. Mr. Tchenguiz will get control of 1,300 Somerfield and Kwik Save stores. Somerfield is based in Bristol, England. (Bloomberg News)

GLOBALIZATION exacted a toll on Delphi workers, who until now had been able to hold onto their generous wages and benefits, as the company said it would use bankruptcy court protection to cut wages or send jobs overseas. It was a rude shock for some skilled employees, and signaled that automakers were more likely to demand significant cuts in pay and benefits as they negotiated with labor unions. Meanwhile, the Bush administration tried to breathe life into moribund talks on reducing tariffs and subsidies for agriculture. Another corporate scandal erupted, mergers heated up in one industry and Apple sought to extend its lead in mobile media by introducing a video version of its iPod. WORKERS' BLUES -- Delphi is decision to seek bankruptcy protection has set up a showdown with the United Automobile Workers that could presage radical changes in the entire auto industry. Delphi, the country is biggest auto parts maker, told the U.A.W. that it must cut labor costs by two-thirds to compete with companies that make parts in Mexico and China.

APPLE EVERY OTHER DAY The News -- Scarcely a month after Apple introduced its thinnest iPod, Steve Jobs, the company is co-founder and chief executive, was back last week to introduce an iPod that can play video. Behind the News -- The bells and whistles of an Apple product unveiling are never to be ignored, but this time it was wedding bells: iPod and television are the happy couple. The new device can shop online for episodes from some ABC and Disney Channel shows, including from the night before, for about $2 a pop. The move comes after two years of Mr. Jobs is saying that nobody would watch a movie on a two-inch screen. TO BOSTON WE GO The News -- JetBlue said Tuesday that next month it would introduce 10 daily flights between New York and Boston. Behind the News -- It is the kind of airfare that could almost make a Yankee fan want to go into enemy territory: $25 one way, for tickets bought by this Thursday. Thereafter the flight will cost $40 to $120. But the route has long been dominated by the traditional major carriers, and they were not without an answer for JetBlue is latest nudging onto their turf. The next day American Airlines began offering $25 tickets on the same route, and Delta introduced a $40 fare. Take that, rookie. THE FOOT-WIDE JOURNAL The News -- The Wall Street Journal plans to shrink by about the width of the 'Street' in its banner. Behind the News -- The measure comes on the heels of The Journal is plan to shrink its international edition to tabloid size, starting next month. Both moves are in part a response to the increase in the cost of newsprint, an industrywide concern that has led other papers to similar decisions. Making The Journal smaller is expected to save its owner, Dow Jones, about $18 million a year. The company has said that it expected the smaller size to be more appealing to readers. ANOTHER GOOD THING? The News -- Martha Stewart is taking on a new partner, the housing developer KB Homes. The deal calls for a subdivision in Cary, N.C., to incorporate the style of Ms. Stewart is own homes into its 650 houses. Behind the News -- Before anyone who wants to live like Martha packs up the free-range chickens and heads to Cary, there are one or two questions to consider: one, is the housing industry heading into a downturn, and two, is Ms. Stewart is company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, whose stock has fallen since March, diluting its brand as it branches into areas like satellite radio and music producing? YOU'VE GOT AOL! The News -- AOL.com has positioned itself as a free Web portal in recent months, with much of the content that used to be available only to subscribers now open to everyone. Last week, Time Warner, AOL is parent, officially unveiled the advertising campaign for it (at a cost estimated at $50 million). Behind the News -- The paying user continues to flee AOL, but Web sites that are part of it -- Moviefone, Mapquest, Netscape -- are a draw. That appeal may be behind talks between Time Warner and others regarding potential investments in AOL. Microsoft, Google, Comcast and Yahoo have been named as suitors or potential suitors.

THE introduction of Apple is video iPod last Wednesday was greeted as an epochal event. The portable, personal, digital world -- as you have no doubt heard by now -- is here, and there is no turning back. And just as it took the vision and brio of Steve Jobs, Apple is founder, to drag the music industry into the 21st century with the iPod and the iTunes online music store, it was only a matter of time before he would do the same with what quaintly used to be known as the moving image. And so, the video iPod. And with it, Mr. Jobs is particularly clever coup: sealing a deal with his quasi-estranged partner, the Walt Disney Company, to distribute downloaded versions of such hit Disney-produced shows as ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Lost'' on the new gizmo, at $1.99 each. It is not exactly 500 channels of entertainment, but it is a good anchor tenant, supplemented by pay-per-download music videos and other clever features, such as films from Mr. Jobs' other outpost, the animation studio Pixar.

It was tremendously busy at the Staten Island Mall last weekend, but not for the usual reasons. No one flipped through the 2006 Orlando Bloom calendars at Day by Day Calendar Company, nor was there interest in the colorful bulk sweets at Candylicious. No lines materialized for the hydro-massage ''Spa Capsule'' chamber, even at the reasonable rate of $10 for seven minutes. Instead, mallgoers cheerfully elbowed their way into a new store with big glass windows and only a shining white silhouette of an apple to serve as its name. For its second retail location in New York after its two-story bazaar in SoHo, Apple had chosen Staten Island. And although the island might seem an unlikely choice for a new Apple store ahead of supposedly hipper city districts, the decision seemed a smart one, at least judging by the crowds on its opening day, Oct. 15.

Betrayed by his superiors and fellow troopers, Chirico Cuvie has to fight his way out of a military prison, killing guards and dodging machine-gun fire. He survives -- a remarkable feat made all the more astonishing by the fact that he is smaller than a matchbook. Nine days after Apple introduced the video iPod, the distributor Central Park Media announced plans to provide anime -- including the adventures of Chirico Cuvie in the series ''Armored Trooper Votoms.'' Visitors to the company is Web site (www.centralparkmedia.com/ipod/) can download ''Votoms,'' a Japanese adventure series, and trailers for other anime shows. ''One of the interesting things about anime fans is that they are known to be early adopters of new technology,'' said Newton Grant, of Central Park Media. ''Anime fans were among the first to adopt the DVD player and video-game-type of electronics,'' he said. ''So we thought it was only natural to move on to the iPod.''

Just before the lights dimmed in the Rose Theater on Thursday night, a voice announced that while the use of cellphones was prohibited, hand-clapping, foot-stomping and cries of ''Aw, yeah!'' were all welcome forms of audience participation. It was a hokier introduction than one might have expected from a concert called ''Wynton With Strings.'' But in a way, it suited both subject and setting. Wynton Marsalis has built his legend on the premise of an elevated yet approachable music -- America is Classical Music, let is say, but also an incorrigibly down-home gumbo. His primary instrument, aside from the trumpet, has been the apparatus of Jazz at Lincoln Center, which employs him as artistic director in much the same way that Apple employs Steve Jobs as chief executive. ''Wynton With Strings'' arrived several days after the organization is fall gala, a black-tie affair that celebrated Mr. Marsalis is 25-year solo career, and reportedly raised nearly $2 million.

Apple is wildly popular iPod has a well-known Achilles' heel: over time, its rechargeable battery tends to lose its capacity to hold a charge. Apple is begrudging solution has been a cumbersome mail-in program that replaces the entire iPod with a reconditioned one for $60. This fall, Sonnet Technologies released a line of high-capacity 3.2-volt batteries for all iPods except the new ultra-small iPod Shuffle and Nano. Sonnet executives say their products will play up to 78 percent longer than the original iPod batteries.

What were they waiting for? It is just over a month since the Apple chief executive, Steve Jobs, and Robert Iger, head of Disney, announced that they would be selling hit shows like ABC is ''Lost'' for viewing on the new iPod. Now it seems like every big company in the industry has come up with a nontraditional twist on delivering television shows -- a quantum leap in barely six weeks. CBS plans to sell reruns of shows like ''CSI'' on Comcast. NBC Universal will do the same for the likes of ''Law & Order: SVU'' over DirecTV. Warner Brothers will offer reruns of ''Wonder Woman'' and ''Welcome Back, Kotter'' over a new Internet service to those whose nostalgia overcomes their critical faculties. And TiVo just announced that its digital recorders will soon be able to download any show onto Apple is little iPods. The networks and production companies apparently were huddled at the edge of the precipice, waiting for one of them -- in this case, the brave Mr. Iger -- to jump first.

To the Editor: ''Cancún is Damage Includes Its Image,'' Nov. 6, painted a misleading picture, saying that charter tour operators abandoned passengers in Cancún after Hurricane Wilma. This is simply not true. On Oct. 26, Apple Vacations, the largest tour operator to Mexico, flew 13 USA 3000 flights into Cancún to repatriate more than 2,000 passengers.

TIVO TAKEOUT The News -- On Monday, TiVo, the maker of digital video recorders, announced that its subscribers will be able to transfer recorded television programs onto their Apple video iPods and Sony handheld PSP game machines. The new service builds on the company is TiVo to Go feature, which allows some subscribers to transfer shows to a laptop or personal computer. Behind the News -- The television networks have yet another reason to hate TiVo, which first encroached on their turf by offering viewers the ability to watch television shows when they wanted, without the commercials. Now, TiVo could hurt the networks' attempts to develop another revenue stream by selling shows by the episode. For instance, ABC plans to sell downloads of ''Desperate Housewives'' on Apple iPods for 99 cents. But why pay, when you can download from TiVo for free? X-GAMES BEGIN The News -- Microsoft released its Xbox 360, its next-generation game machine, at midnight on Tuesday. Buyers lined up for hours to be among the first to purchase it. Behind the News -- Industry analysts said the early buzz around the Xbox 360 might not mean much in the long run. The real question is whether the 360 can outsell Sony is next-generation game console, PlayStation 3, which is not due out until spring. LIBRARY DOWNLOAD The News -- Google gave $3 million to help the Library of Congress build a World Digital Library on the Web. For the project, the National Library of Egypt has already agreed to digitize documents of Islamic science from the 10th century. Behind the News -- Google is gift may be good public relations. The Library of Congress emphasized that Google is gift comes with no strings attached and no copyright problems. That would be welcome news for Google, which has faced copyright issues because of its Book Search project, a book- scanning effort in partnership with five research libraries. GOODNIGHT, TED The News -- On Tuesday, Ted Koppel, the anchor of ''Nightline'' ended his 25-year reign as late night is Mr. Serious. Behind the News -- Will ''Nightline'' survive? Under Mr. Koppel, it has struggled in the ratings, generally falling behind NBC is ''The Tonight Show With Jay Leno'' and CBS is ''Late Show With David Letterman.'' Now, three anchors will replace Mr. Koppel, and it is unknown how quickly ABC expects ratings success.

GREENFIELD -- Harriet Copelin. Formerly of Hartland, VT and New York City, died Friday, November 25, 2005 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, after a long illness. She was 82 years old. She is survived by her five children; Juliet Six & Faith Lewis both of Washington, DC, Gordon Greenfield Jr. of Norwich, VT, Hope Greenfield of Oldwick, NJ, and James Greenfield of New York City; by a brother, Donald Copelin of Ketchum, ID; and by 8 grandchildren. Her husband of 60 years, Gordon Greenfield, died this past January. Harriet Greenfield was best known for her dedication to charitable causes, especially those involving children. In 1995 she received the Helenka Pantaleoni Award from the U.S. Committee for UNICEF for her work as Founder and CoChair of the New York City Chapter. She served on the Board of the Youth Counseling League and the World Adoption International Fund (WAIF). In the 1980 is she was Chairman of the Women is Division of The New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation. She joined the staff of The National Red Cross in 1984 to develop their Jr. Committee where she earned The Steuben Apple Award. She also joined her husband as a patron of music in New York, as a key fundraiser for the Opera Orchestra Society. Additionally, she served as President of the Board of Immigration and Refugee Services of America (IRSA), and its subsidiary, The U.S. Committee for Refugees (USCR), from 1993-1997, and on its Board from 1989 to 2001. In Vermont, she served on the Boards of Historic Windsor and Lebanon College, Lebanon, NH. Harriet Greenfield, born in Philadelphia, was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, 1943. A burial service will be held in December in Hartland, VT. Please send donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida.

I OWN a 47-inch Samsung high-definition television. My wife and I bought it a couple of years ago, when HDTV prices were still in the stratosphere, but we have never had a moment of buyer is remorse. I love the thing: the large screen, the vivid colors, the better-than-real-life picture. I can get downright rhapsodic talking up the joys of high definition; indeed, I become annoyed now when I am forced to watch a program on ''ordinary'' TV because it is not available on high definition. Once you have been down the high-def path, you do not want to go back. Which is also why I have been so perplexed by all the hoopla surrounding the Disney-Apple deal announced a few months ago. In case you have been living in a media-deprived cave, Disney, owner of the ABC television network, agreed to allow people to download weekly episodes of two of its most popular shows, ''Desperate Housewives'' and ''Lost,'' onto an iPod, a wonderful device for music, but one whose tiny screen forces you to squint to see video images. It is not free, either. Just as Apple charges 99 cents to download a song, it is charging $1.99 for each episode of the shows.

With the Acquisition of DreamWorks SKG, A Stunning Coup for Paramount Pictures The phone rang at David Geffen is house on Friday, Dec. 2. It was Brad Grey, the chairman of Paramount Pictures. He was looking to break up a deal Mr. Geffen was on the verge of making to sell his studio, DreamWorks SKG, to NBC-Universal. Mr. Geffen was skeptical. Paramount had expressed interest in buying DreamWorks three months earlier. ''We have been through this before,'' warned Mr. Geffen. He had pulled off a stunning coup, snatching DreamWorks from the grasp of NBC-Universal. On Fiona Apple is new album, ''Extraordinary Machine,'' her ''Better Version of Me'' trumpets a personality upgrade. But every incarnation of this 28-year-old singer-songwriter has been fascinating, from the ferocious teenage provocateur of her 1996 debut, ''Tidal,'' to the fragile poet-warrior of the 1999 follow-up album, ''When the Pawn,'' to the current muscular songwriter whose work is so structurally sound it is hard to imagine that production indecision held up its release for years. At her packed show at the Nokia Theater in Midtown on Sunday, when Ms. Apple admitted ambivalence about being onstage, a devotee admonished, ''It is where you belong, honey!'' But in the years after the disappointing sales of ''When the Pawn,'' Ms. Apple has confessed to being happier sitting in her yard carving pine cones with razor blades. Resistance to fame, evidenced most famously by her petulant outburst at 1997 is MTV Awards, has always endeared her to fans. But they also want her to make music, lobbying for the release of the delayed new record after a scrapped version, made with Jon Brion as producer, leaked online last year.

You already knew that computer nerds get pretty serious about their chosen passion. But this gallery of geek tattoos shows just how far they will go to prove it. Apple logos, old 8-bit Atari characters, knuckle tattoos that spell the word DOWNLOAD only when the hands are clasped--it is all here, for your eye-popping pleasure.

1. Fiona Apple: 'Extraordinary Machine' (Epic). Take 2 of this long-awaited, prematurely leaked album is the keeper. On the finished album, a little bit of Jon Brion is surreal cabaret orchestration brackets the newer stripped-down, focused versions of the songs. Ms. Apple continues her obsessive self-examination and convoluted thoughts of betrayal and regret, but now adds something: enough distance for some wry perspective. 2. M.I.A.: 'Arular' (Interscope). The means are modest: singsong choruses that could be playground chants, sparse tracks made with sounds from cheap synthesizers and drum machines. But the ambitions of M.I.A., a refugee from the civil war in Sri Lanka who went to art school in London, are huge and largely fulfilled on ''Arular,'' her debut album. The raps glance at violence, displacement, lust and determination in tracks that are irresistibly, incessantly danceable. 3. Shakira: 'Fijación Oral Vol. 1' (Epic). This is pop 2005: catchy songs about love found and (even better) lost that casually toss together reggaetón, bossa nova, Colombian cumbia, chanson and half a dozen varieties of rock, for starters. It all suits a voice that can be insouciant, sultry or desperately impassioned, and a songwriter whose globe-hopping comes naturally. 4. Sufjan Steves: 'Illinois' (Asthmatic Kitty). Songs about significant events and characters in Illinois -- the second of the 50 states Mr. Steves plans to write albums about -- are at once grandly orchestrated, homespun and emotionally resonant. With his large supporting cast, Mr. Steves finds ways to take history personally. 5. The Frames: 'Burn the Maps' (Anti-). If Radiohead had a love life but stayed just as bleak, it would sound like the Frames on this album of heartsick, craggy, majestic rock songs that never trade drama for melodrama. 6. Bright Eyes: 'Digital Ash in a Digital Urn' (Saddle Creek). Conor Oberst, a k a Bright Eyes, released two albums simultaneously in 2005: the folk-rocking ''I am Wide Awake, It is Morning'' and the far more electronic ''Digital Ash in a Digital Urn.'' Both are among the year is best albums. Yet where ''Wide Awake'' simply adds to Mr. Oberst is stockpile of brilliantly observed songs about personal matters like ambition and casual sex, ''Digital Ash'' uses its ricocheting, disembodied sounds to contemplate time, war, death and the meaning of life. 7. Bettye LaVette: 'I have Got My Own Hell to Raise' (Anti-). It seems all too conceptual to have a 59-year-old soul-music trouper sing a collection of songs by women. But Ms. LaVette is flinty voice and lean, bluesy, cannily arranged band tear into every song, turning old wounds into tokens of survival. 8. Stephen Malkmus: 'Face the Truth' (Matador). Three albums after the breakup of Pavement, his definitive 1990 is indie-rock band, Stephen Malkmus remains waywardly alternative. His lyrics fling aperçus at life, art and commerce, while his tunes melt down the old verse-chorus-verse, deploy banjos and wobbly synthesizers, amble off on jam-band tangents, plunge into garage-rock or do the acoustic tango. He is as smart as he is mercurial. 9. Konono No. 1: 'Congotronics' (Crammed Discs). Take traditional, polyrhythmic thumb-piano trance music from Congo, plinking away in dizzying syncopated patterns. To crank it up for big outdoor parties, run it through buzzy pickups and amplifiers made from, among other things, scavenged car parts. The result is electric Minimalism that is exuberant and relentless, changing from percolating to hypnotic to a tingle that reaches deep into the nervous system. 10. Sleater-Kinney: 'The Woods' (Sub Pop). Distortion is everywhere on ''The Woods,'' Sleater-Kinney is seventh album, and it brings a nervy intensity to songs already worked up. With just two guitars, drums and Corin Tucker is banshee wail, Sleater-Kinney can sound as immense as a metal band and as bristling and unkempt as their indie-rock beginnings. Singing about love and war, truth and spectacle, the trio still plays as if everything were at stake. Top Songs: Bruce Springsteen: ''Devils & Dust'' Amerie: ''1 Thing'' Irma Thomas: ''Back Water Blues'' Miranda Lambert: ''Kerosene'' Kanye West: ''Gold Digger''

The D-Link MediaLounge DSM-120 does most media streaming devices one better. Products like the Apple AirPort Express can transmit MP3 is and other music files stored on networked computers, but the DSM-120 can also play music when the computers are turned off. IT was like a TV Land rerun marathon this week, with Boston Scientific topping Johnson & Johnson is bid for Guidant, the Dow eclipsing 11,000, General Motors scrambling to regain market share and Apple being hailed as a blisteringly hot tech stock. There was even another sex-discrimination suit on Wall Street. Some things were new, however. China surpassed some Western industrial powerhouses with the size of its economy, and its global trade surplus set a record. FIGHT TO THE START -- It is a strange kind of bidding war when a last-minute offer from the underdog is about the same as the opening bid made by the heavily favored industry giant. But that is the case in the battle for Guidant, a maker of implantable heart devices.

CHIP CHANGE The News -- Apple is Chairman, Steve Jobs, and Intel is chief executive, Paul Otellini, introduced Apple is first Macintosh computers that use processing chips from Intel. Behind the News -- The shift came several months ahead of schedule, and surprised analysts. It was only last spring that Apple said it would stop using I.B.M. processors, a decision that shook up the semiconductor industry. The move to Intel chips was also something of a shock, since Intel has long been an ally of Apple is rival, Microsoft. CHANGE OF AIR The News -- After more than two decades on terrestrial radio, the shock jock Howard Stern began broadcasting by satellite. Behind the News -- The switch is a gamble for Sirius Satellite Radio, which is paying Mr. Stern hundreds of millions of dollars in hopes of attracting more listeners willing to pay a monthly subscription fee. It is also something of a gamble for Mr. Stern, who earned his bad-boy reputation by pushing up against Federal Communications Commission standards on indecency. The new show featured plenty of foul language since, as a satellite show, it falls outside the F.C.C. is purview. He no longer has the agency to kick around. FACE CHANGE The News -- The United States Mint introduced a new version of the nickel, with the portrait of Thomas Jefferson facing front. Behind the News -- The Treasury has been making a lot of changes lately, particularly in paper money, emphasizing new anticounterfeiting technologies. The changes to the nickel have little to do with technology but may upset purists just the same. In the 97 years that presidents have been stamped on coins, never has one been shown in anything other than profile. Purists had better get used to the new look, however: no further changes to the nickel are in the works. CHANGING SCENERY The News -- Mehmet Ali Agca, a Turk who shot Pope John Paul II in St. Peter is Square in 1981, was released from prison in Istanbul. Behind the News -- The release was strongly criticized by Turkey is justice minister, who said it offended the ''public conscience'' and ordered a review. Mr. Agca, 48, had been convicted not only of shooting the pope but of killing a Turkish journalist. He will remain free while the appeal is heard. But he is also obligated to fulfill his mandatory military service, which he missed while in prison. CHANGE OF HEART The News -- The skier Bode Miller apologized for statements he made that suggested he had raced while under the influence of alcohol. Behind the News -- Miller, the best all-around skier the United States has ever produced, had been under pressure from American and international ski officials to apologize after his remarks on ''60 Minutes.'' While he apologized, he neither admitted nor denied that he had raced after drinking, and he spoke for little more than two minutes without taking questions. All of which should add to his reputation as an iconoclastic free spirit as he heads to the Olympics next month.

A couple of years ago, nothing seemed less likely than the sale of Pixar to the Walt Disney Company. At the time, it looked as if the two companies would not even be able to agree on the terms of their distribution deal, which gave Disney, then run by Michael Eisner, an unfair stake in Pixar is films, according to Pixar is chief executive, Steve Jobs. Now Mr. Eisner is gone, and on Tuesday Disney is board approved an offer of $7.4 billion, about $59 a share, to acquire Pixar, whose major shareholder is Mr. Jobs. The deal now goes to the Pixar board. A company like that -- and a figure like Mr. Jobs, notable for his dynamic role at both Apple and Pixar -- does not let itself be bought for money alone, though the money is certainly enticing enough. This is really an opportunity to infect, and change, the creative culture of Disney, which, back in its founder is day, used to be one of the most creative places around.

Apple to Offer Computers That Can Run Both Macintosh and Windows Systems Two decades after the first Macintosh computer arrived, Apple said that it would offer users of its latest models a simple way to run both the Microsoft Windows operating system and its own. That means a single Apple will run the universe of programs written for either the Mac or Windows. Apple is stock jumped almost 10 percent on the news. Everyone saw it coming. First, Apple chose Intel, synonymous with Microsoft, to make chips for a new line of personal computers. Now Apple has announced Boot Camp, which will allow some versions of Windows to run more or less natively on an Apple machine. How you feel about this depends very much on whether you are a Windows or an Apple person. From one angle, Boot Camp looks like a sensible effort to expand Apple is slice of the personal computer market. So far, switching from a Windows desktop to a much sleeker Mac has meant abandoning Windows for Apple is Mac OSX operating system. That means giving up some highly specialized applications for which there is no Apple equivalent. For better or worse, Apple has never quite been able to destroy the preconception that Windows belongs to business in roughly the same way that Apple belongs to the arts. An Apple that can run Windows will do away with such distinctions.

THE BRONX The News -- The baseball season opened with the Yankees winning a big one: the New York City Council approved plans for a new $800 million stadium. Behind the News -- The vote was the last real hurdle in a decades-long quest for a new stadium. The Yankees at one point threatened to move the team to New Jersey, and more recently Manhattan had been in the running. But in the end the team opted for a site next to the existing stadium in the South Bronx. The Council went along, over objections from neighborhood residents that the project would usurp parkland. SILICON VALLEY The News -- Apple said it would introduce software to enable its Macintosh computers to run the Microsoft Windows operating system as well as its own. Behind the News -- For Apple, which had long ignored and even mocked Microsoft is product, the decision was nothing short of revolutionary. But it was based on a simple business calculus: limiting its computers to a single operating system had limited the company is growth. If Macintoshes can run the vast array of Windows-only software, Apple may grab more than its current 5 percent share of the PC market. WASHINGTON The News -- Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice lobbied Congress to support the administration is effort to aid India is nuclear power program. Behind the News -- Legislators had criticized the deal, citing concerns over India is nuclear weapons program. Ms. Rice sought to reassure the critics, saying she would push India to safeguard its civilian plants and block exports of weapons-making material. The calming words had an effect: several lawmakers offered qualified support for the agreement, leaving the White House optimistic that it would be approved. ISRAEL The News -- The Kadima Party, the winner in Israeli elections last month, said it would form a coalition with the Labor Party. Behind the News -- The announcement does not quite settle the issue of what the new government will look like, as two or three smaller parties will be needed to form a parliamentary majority. But it goes a long way toward ensuring the continuation of the policies of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who is incapacitated by a coma. The parties agree on critical policy, including the removal of more Israeli settlements from the West Bank. TV LAND The News -- Katie Couric, a fixture on NBC is ''Today'' for 15 years, will join CBS, where she will anchor the evening newscast. Behind the News -- For CBS, which courted Ms. Couric for a year, the move is an effort to attract new viewers to its newscast, a ratings also-ran in recent years. The hope is that some of her legions of fans who have made ''Today'' a ratings hit will start watching her at night. CBS may also be thinking that ''Today'' may stumble without her, creating an opening for the network is morning show, which is even more of a ratings laggard.

It was a good year to be a Beatles fan in 1965, the year of ''Help!'' and ''Rubber Soul.'' It was also the year the group is publishing company, Northern Songs, went public. That early step in the commodification of the Beatles culminated in, among other things, the recent $200 million refinancing of Michael Jackson, the current co-owner of the Northern Songs catalog. Yesterday, another curious episode in the band is business history came to an apparent close in Britain, where a judge ruled against Applerps, the Beatles' management company, in its 2003 suit against Apple. The suit is origin was in Apple is creation of iTunes, which Applerps interpreted as a violation of a 1991 agreement that would, in its opinion, have prevented the other Apple from distributing music. (The agreement would also have prevented Applerps from making computers.) Applerps, which was founded in 1968 to gather the Beatles' business interests under one roof, seems to have been born for trouble. Its logo, designed by Gene Mahon, is as clean and crisp as it ever was, but to many observers the company appears to have done a better of spawning lawsuits over the years than of fostering the Beatles' interests.

FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY -- Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.) FANNIE AND FREDDIE -- At the New York Yacht Club, a few people with some strong opinions about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the huge government-sponsored mortgage packagers, will be on hand for a panel discussion about how the two should be regulated -- or perhaps punished. Randal Quarles, the Treasury under secretary for domestic finance, and James Lockhart III, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, both of whom have been outspoken about the management and accounting scandals at the two companies, will be offering their views. (Wednesday.) A FLURRY OF REPORTS -- So many economic indicators, so little time. There will be updates on inflation with the Producer Price Index for June (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for June (Wednesday). Other reports: industrial production and capacity utilization for June (Monday); June housing starts (Wednesday); and Federal Reserve minutes for June and the Conference Board is leading economic indicators (Thursday). They were bundled up in candy-apple red outside the Madison Avenue offices of Sony BMG Music Entertainment one frigid morning in early 2005, petitioning for the release of a new album by their idol: ''We want Fiona! We want Fiona!'' It had been five years since the last record by Fiona Apple, above, and fans were engaging in panicked speculation about the hold-up: Had a new album been rejected by her label? Was Ms. Apple too much of a perfectionist to let it go? Whatever the reason, ''Extraordinary Machine'' (Epic), released in October, was well worth the wait. In songs with thick, jazzy textures and playful orchestral arrangements, Ms. Apple studied the failure of relationships through a lens of blame and regret, sometimes punching angrily at her piano and sometimes flitting through an anachronistic falsetto fantasy. Through it all, she sang as if she were at an exquisitely painful -- and revealing -- couples' therapy session. (''I think he let me down when he did not disappoint me.'') If Ms. Apple is anguished flagellations were what her fans risked frostbite to demand, they got more than enough. On her first major tour since the album is release, she plays with Damien Rice, a singer-songwriter who surrounds his breathy music with florid strings and even more florid self-pity. AOL is about to introduce a vastly expanded online video area, an important part of its effort to attract a new audience to replace that of its rapidly declining subscription service. For the first time it will also sell commercial-free downloads, competing with Apple is iTunes Music Store and Google Video.

In a darkened garage here, Steve Perlman is giving digital actors a whole new face. A former Apple engineer who previously co-founded WebTV Networks and the set-top box firm Moxi, Mr. Perlman is now putting the finishing touches on Contour, a futuristic camera system that will add photorealistic three-dimensional effects to digital entertainment. The new system will be introduced today at the Siggraph computer graphics conference in Boston, and effects created with it could start appearing as early as next year.

DO WE HEAR A PAUSE? -- The central economic news of the week will emerge from the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which will decide whether to raise the benchmark short-term interest rate -- now at 5.25 percent -- yet another time. On the one hand, many economists predict that the Fed will leave things unchanged, which would be welcome news for investors, but then again, who knows? The dearth of one-handed economists is legendary. (Tuesday.) ECONOMIC MEASUREMENTS -- Few if any fireworks are expected from the coming crop of economic reports, but expectations can always be wrong. Leading off the week will be the Federal Reserve is consumer credit report for June (Monday), followed by second-quarter productivity figures (Tuesday), wholesale trade data for June (Wednesday), trade deficit figures for June (Thursday) and, on Friday, import prices for July, retail sales for July and business inventories for June. CORE CONSTITUENCY -- The annual worldwide developers conference of Apple will be held all week, starting Monday, in San Francisco. Apple calls it its ' amost important annual event for hardware and software developers, including in-house developers, computational scientists, I.T. managers and system administrators.'' But given the disclosure last week that the company had found new irregularities in its handling of stock options and that it would be revising some financial statements, code writers will probably not be the only ones waiting eagerly to hear what Steve Jobs, Apple is chief executive, has to say. The highlights include: Priceline.com (Monday); Cablevision Systems, Cisco Systems and the News Corporation (Tuesday); Aramark, Cendant, the Interpublic Group of Companies, Viacom and Walt Disney (Wednesday); and Expedia, J. C. Penney, Kohl is and Target (Thursday).

In the New Solar System, Pluto Is a 'Dwarf Planet' In what many scientists described as a triumph of science over sentiment, Pluto has been demoted to the status of a ' wouldwarf planet.'' Astronomers, after years of wrangling, voted on a reclassification of the solar system. In the new system there are eight planets, at least three dwarf planets, and tens of thousands of so-called smaller solar system bodies, like comets and asteroids. The outcome completed a stunning turnaround from a week ago, when the assembled astronomers were presented a proposal that would have increased the number of planets in the solar system to 12, including Pluto. FOOD AND BEVERAGES The News -- Coca-Cola and Pepsi sought to overturn partial bans on their soft drinks in many parts of India. Behind the News -- The bans were instituted after an advocacy group announced the results of studies showing the beverages contained on average more than 24 times the safe limits of pesticides. Coca-Cola and Pepsi say their products are safe. But the companies are generally perceived as having bungled their response to the crisis, misjudging how quickly politicians would latch on to the advocacy group is report, playing to widespread wariness of multinationals. HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS The News -- Federal researchers concluded that only a contact-lens solution made by Bausch & Lomb contributed to an outbreak of fungal eye infections earlier this year. Behind the News -- The company had argued that customers who failed to clean their lenses properly were largely at fault. But the report pointed the finger at Bausch & Lomb is ReNu With MoistureLoc. A total recall of the product last spring has been effective; the number of new infections is near zero. But the recall has affected the company is bottom line: it announced profits would be down 78 percent this year. COMPUTERS The News -- A top executive of AOL resigned after the disclosure that the company had released information about Web searches by 650,000 customers. Behind the News -- The chief technology officer, Maureen Govern, was deemed ultimately responsible for the release; two employees under her were fired. The company said it would tighten data-privacy rules and retrain employees. But online privacy advocates said AOL is moves were not enough, and warned that the problems of keeping data confidential were endemic to the search-engine industry. ONLINE SERVICES The News -- Apple said it was recalling nearly two million laptop batteries, saying they posed a fire hazard. Behind the News -- The announcement came just a week after Dell said it would recall about four million batteries for the same reason. Together they constitute by far the largest recall in the consumer electronics industry. For Sony, which made the batteries involved in both recalls, it was more bad news. The company is reputation for innovative design has suffered in recent years; now its reputation for quality has taken a hit, too. MOVIES The News -- Paramount ended its 14-year relationship with Tom Cruise, saying the actor is recent conduct had been unacceptable. Behind the News -- Mr. Cruise is people insisted he had not been fired but had quit. The dispute quickly escalated, with many agents, producers and other impresarios choosing sides. While Mr. Cruise is behavior -- which included remarks against psychiatry and in favor of Scientology -- was at issue, this being Hollywood, so was money. The weak opening take of his latest film convinced many Paramount executives that Mr. Cruise was becoming an albatross.

Dell Inc. has had its share of headaches recently, including a recall of 4.1 million batteries subject to spontaneous combustion, and the poaching of executives (four since Aug. 17) by Lenovo. Apple was forced to recall a similar battery in 1.1 million of its laptops. The batteries were made for both companies by Sony.

Apple said yesterday that the chief executive of Google, Eric Schmidt, was joining its board, linking two of Silicon Valley is most iconic – and maverick – companies.
The alliance between Google and Apple may make the prospect of outdueling Microsoft is empire better than ever.

When Eric Schmidt, Google is chief executive, was named to Apple is board this week, it did more than signal a potential alliance between powerful companies. It touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the move: Apple is co-founder, Steve Jobs. ''The old social networks in Silicon Valley run very deep,'' noted AnnaLee Saxenian, a leading scholar of the industry and dean of the School of Information at the University of California, Berkeley. ''And this reminds us that Silicon Valley has a common enemy to the north.''

OVER the past two weeks Apple and Dell Computer have recalled approximately six million lithium-ion batteries powering their notebook computers. The batteries, all made by Sony, had an annoying problem: they were prone to explode. While we as consumers might wonder why vendors are selling batteries intended to go in pockets and briefcases that have greater energy storage density than dynamite, recent history actually shows that we will accept almost any risk for more power. Lithium-ion is just the latest in a succession of relatively toxic rechargeable battery technologies, each intended to pack more available electrons in smaller and smaller packages, with li-ion besting the field by a resounding five times, explosions be damned. Earlier rechargeable batteries were mainly nickel-cadmium (these can explode, too, if short-circuited) and nickel-metal-hydride (the most benign rechargeable, these are in your Toyota Prius, natch).

THE TIME EVOLUTION -- For most of the 20th century, under the influence of its founder, Henry Luce, Time magazine spoke in a single authoritative voice that reflected the world back to its readers. Now Richard Stengel, the new managing editor of Time, wants to change the metaphor. His plan is to fill the pages of Time with more essays and news analysis, give the magazine a sharper point of view and draw more brand-name journalists into the fold. If this sounds familiar, it may be that Mr. Stengel wants Time to be a little more like its chief rival, Newsweek. Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Jeff Hare 95 minutes Marinated in egg cream and garnished with lox and onions, ''Checking Out'' is more sitcom-ready Jewish than a weekend in the Catskills circa 1950. Based on a 1976 play by Allen Swift, the movie revolves around 90-year-old Morris Applebaum (Peter Falk), a retired Shakespearean actor for whom every moment, even his death, is a performance. In response to a letter he has sent advertising his imminent suicide, Morris is grown children converge on his luxurious New York apartment, dragging their emotional baggage and a repertory of corny one-liners with them.

Sony has refused to identify all the computer makers that may be using defective batteries that can cause laptop computers to catch fire, contending that disclosure is up to the PC makers affected. Toshiba said yesterday that it would replace 830,000 Sony batteries, and Dell recalled 100,000 units on top of the 4.1 million it had announced earlier. Lenovo, I.B.M. and Apple have also announced recalls that now total 7.7 million units. When Apple withdrew 1.8 million batteries in August, Sony released a statement saying it did not anticipate further recalls. Sony said on Aug. 24 that battery replacements for Dell and Apple notebooks would cost the company 20 billion yen to 30 billion yen ($170 million to $254 million). It did not say how much the latest recall would cost.

Apple moved last week to answer questions about its problems with stock options, but in the end it left plenty unanswered, including the role played by Fred Anderson, who resigned Wednesday from the company is board. Mr. Anderson resigned after a special committee of directors disclosed that it had found irregularities with stock option grants made between 1997 and 2002, a period when he served as chief financial officer. The company said only that Mr. Anderson believed that it was ''in Apple is best interests'' that he leave the board.

Can Microsoft is new music player, Zune, knock the iPod off its perch as the must-have gadget of the new millennium? The early reviews have been negative: David Pogue of The New York Times, while admiring the portable music player is cool looks, effectively called it a me-too product, an effort by Microsoft to cash in on the market that its arch-rival, Apple, created with the iPod and still dominates. Zune is appearance and functionality will inevitably be compared with the iPod and, since the bar is set so high, will no doubt be found wanting. But product cycles turn fast, and thanks to the fragility of the iPod - and the unwillingness of Apple to invest much in repair service - there is a generation of consumers out there who now treat a $300 gadget as disposable. Then there is the junkyard littered with companies that underestimated the marketing power of Microsoft. This race may not be close yet, but it is still too young to call.

IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July ''catastrophic.'' Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share. TOWARD A BETTER CANAL -- Panamanians will vote in a referendum over whether to add a third set of locks to the Panama Canal (Sunday). The country took over the canal from the United States in 1999, and although there seems to be broad agreement that the project would help bring the outdated canal up to modern standards -- making room for larger ships, for instance, and cutting wait times for vessels lingering offshore -- many Panamanians are skeptical. There is concern, among other things, that the government is $5.2 billion price tag for the seven-year project is a low estimate. Meanwhile, Nicaragua is president has proposed spending $18 billion to build a wider alternative to the Panama Canal. INDICATORS DU JOUR -- For economic indicators, the focus this week will be on inflation, with the release of the Producer Price Index for September (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for September (Wednesday). Other reports scheduled for release this week are industrial production and capacity utilization for September (Tuesday); housing starts for September (Wednesday); and leading economic indicators (Thursday). A MONSTER EARNINGS WEEK -- Earnings season gets into full swing with some big names in the Dow. Highlights will include: Intel, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, McClatchy, Merrill Lynch, Motorola and Yahoo (Tuesday); AMR, Apple, Boston Scientific, eBay, General Dynamics and JP Morgan Chase (Wednesday); Bank of America, Citigroup, Coca-Cola, Dow Jones, Google, Honeywell, Eli Lilly, McDonald is, Nokia, Southwest Airlines, the Tribune Company and Wyeth (Thursday); and 3M and Merck (Friday).

Apple says strong sales of its Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players led to 27 percent rise in its fiscal fourth-quarter profit; Apple is shares rise 6 percent in after-hours trading; reports net income of $546 million, up from $430 million year earlier; revenue was $4.84 billion, increase of nearly 32 percent from $3.68 billion year before; Macintosh sales accounted for 58 percent of revenue in quarter; chief executive Steve Jobs and chief financial officer Peter Oppenheimer comment
SAN FRANCISCO — Apple shares have surged as a result of 27 percent growth in quarterly profit on strong Macintosh and iPod sales.

APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1] VIRTUAL WORLD ADVERTISING -- Companies including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems and Nissan are testing the next frontier in Internet advertising: placing ads into online virtual worlds like Second Life and Virtual Laguna Beach. Some online users worry that the corporate intrusion will spoil their virtual paradises. [C1] MICROSOFT LOOKS AT CHIP DESIGN -- After wedding its software to Intel is processors for decades, Microsoft is looking to its own research labs for as a new source in future chip design. One goal of the project is to give Microsoft more control over hardware and software and the way the interact in new devices. [C3] CONSUMER PRICES FALL -- Falling energy prices helped push consumer prices down sharply last month, but the decline did not entirely dispel inflation worries because the measure of retail prices that excludes food and energy costs held steady at a level still above the Federal Reserve is comfort zone. [C3] NEW AD AGENCY NETWORK -- Three longtime advertising executives are joining forces to start an agency network with an entrepreneurial bent. The agency network, called the Partners Group, aims to grow by encouraging more entrepreneurs to affiliate with the three founders. Advertising [C13] MUSIC INDUSTRY AND YOUTUBE -- Universal Music Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and Warner Music each acquired small stakes in YouTube as part of licensing deals just prior to the sale of the company to Google for $1.65 billion. The three companies now stand to receive as much as $50 million collectively, people involved in the deal said. [C1] A TORRENT OF IMMIGRANT MONEY -- The flow of money from immigrants working in the United States to Latin America has become a torrent, increasing by 51 percent from two years ago to over $45 billion, according to a new study. Where 20 years ago such remittances came from four or five states, today they come nearly every state in the country, the study said. [A24] ELI LILLY CRITICIZED -- Three doctors at the National Institutes of Health have sharply criticized Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote the use of Xigris, an expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, an often deadly blood infection. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors wrote that Lilly had manipulated treatment guidelines to promote Xigris at the expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments. [C12] TIME WARNER CABLE SHARES -- Time Warner Cable said that it would sell shares publicly for the first time, giving investors a chance to own a piece of the country is second-largest cable provider after Comcast. The shares would amount to 16 percent of the company is equity. [C5] EARNINGS RISE AT A.M.D. -- Advanced Micro Devices, which makes computer processors, posted a higher quarterly profit but profit margins fell sharply, hurt by a price war with the rival chipmaker Intel. Advanced Micro said it expected fourth-quarter sales to rise from the previous quarter but did not elaborate. [C4] NBC PLANS CUTBACKS -- NBC will announce a series of cost-cutting measures including some employee layoffs, executives said. The plans will include a relocation of MSNBC, the all-news cable channel owned by NBC from its current home in Secaucus N.J. [C13] VIACOM SEVERANCE -- Viacom plans to pay its former chief executive, Tom Freston, $84.8 million after ousting him last month after less than a year in the top job. Mr. Freston will receive $58.9 million in severance. The remainder will be in deferred compensation, retirement funds and common stock, the company said in a regulatory filing. [C15] BLOOMBERG NEWS NOT FOR SALE -- Mayor Michael Bloomberg has rejected bids for Bloomberg LP, the financial information company that he founded in 1981, and has no immediate intention to sell the business, the company said. The statement came amid speculation that the company might be sold to free up Mr. Bloomberg is vast personal wealth for philanthropic causes. [C1] DOW MOVES BRIEFLY PAST 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average briefly swept past the 12,000 mark for the first time as investors showed optimism about corporate earnings and the economy. Then the blue-chip index pulled back, closing at another record high but short of 12,000. [C15] ONLINE DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. A SPECIAL REPORT -- For mutual fund investors, jubilance over gains in the stock market has been tempered by the realization that many fund managers were caught flat-footed and did not keep pace. A report is at nytimes.com/business. TAXES AND FAITH -- A number of communities around the country are debating whether or not religious organizations should receive property tax breaks. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business.

Apple, the maker of iPod music players, delayed filing its financial statements on Friday for the second time, and said it would restate earnings to account for backdated stock-option grants. Web pages with feeds available often display an orange ''R.S.S.'' or ''XML'' icon. (XML stands for Extensible Markup Language, a standard for creating and coding some forms of Web content.) Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox and the latest version of Apple is Safari all provide the ability to subscribe to R.S.S. feeds and read updates right in a browser. Lawyers for the Beatles are suing to thwart distribution of previously unreleased recordings supposedly made during Ringo Starr is first performance with the band, at the Star Club in Hamburg, West Germany, in 1962, The Associated Press reported. Under the title “Jammin' With the Beatles and Friends, Star Club, Hamburg, 1962,” the eight tracks are said to include Paul McCartney singing Hank Williams is “Lovesick Blues” and Mr. McCartney and John Lennon singing “Ask Me Why.” Applerps, the London company formed by the Beatles, maintains that the songs were taped without their consent, and that Fuego Entertainment of Miami Lakes, Fla., and two sister companies have no right to distribute them. Apple is lawsuit contends that the recordings are of poor quality and that circulating them “dilutes and tarnishes the extraordinarily valuable image associated with the Beatles.” Paul LiCalsi, a lawyer for Applerps, said, “This appears to us to be a garden-variety bootleg recording.” Hugo Cancio, the president of Fuego, said: “Do not claim that these were just bootlegged. It is not like today, that you just go in with a phone or BlackBerry and you record.” He added: “The world deserves to hear these tracks. The fact is that we have it, they do not, and that is what is bothering them.”.

In oil paint, it is a different story, which is good news for the two high school freshmen who are believed to have made marks on his portrait when their United States government class toured the Capitol in St. Paul. “It turns out the ink was not very stubborn and the paintings had enough varnish to keep the ink from seeping below the surface,” Brian Szott, curator of art at the Minnesota Historical Society, said of the vandalism the students are believed to have inflicted on three portraits of governors. Marks were also drawn across the mouths of Elmer Andersen and Harold LeVander. Initial estimates suggested the vandalism would require restoration, costing several thousand dollars. In fact, the repairs cost $175. It took an hour and a mild solvent to remove the ink from the paintings. An investigation is focusing on students from Eastview High School in Apple Valley. Paris — U.S. stocks gained for a fourth day Wednesday as investors snapped up technology shares trading near their cheapest level on record, overpowering earlier declines spurred by economic data depicting a deepening recession. Apple and Microsoft led computer companies in the Standard & Poor is 500 index higher as the group traded for 12.8 times reported earnings. General Motors and Ford Motor, which will make their case for federal bailout funds after the Thanksgiving holiday, rallied more than 14 percent. The SP 500 climbed 0.6 percent to 863.54 after earlier sliding as much as 1.9 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 58.3 points, or 0.7 percent, to 8,537.77. The Nasdaq Composite index added 2.1 percent to 1,495.89. The SP 500 Tuesday climbed for a third day after the deepening recession prompted the Federal Reserve to commit as much as $800 billion to help resuscitate lending to homeowners, consumers and businesses. The index has tumbled 41 percent this year as credit-related losses and writedowns at financial companies worldwide approached $1 trillion, threatening global economic growth. Benchmark indexes also erased an earlier tumble after President-elect Barack Obama picked former Federal Reserve chief Paul Volcker to head an economic advisory board and said he will implement a plan to bolster growth on "day one." Earlier declines in the stock market came after government reports showed orders for durable goods shrank 6.2 percent, twice as much as forecast, and consumer spending declined the most since 2001. "The reality is 2009 is pretty much set up to be a rough year economically," said Hayes Miller, head of the North American investment team at Baring Asset Management.
